dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: of an empty stretch of land parted down the middle by railroad tracks. An Amtrak Commuter crests the horizon, heads TOWARD us. As it gets CLOSER, we GO IN TIGHTER to see --

dialogues.speaker: FACE OF SARA JOHNSON
dialogues.text: 17, pressed at one of its windows.

dialogues.speaker: SARA'S FACE
dialogues.text: distant and lovely and sad. SUPERIMPOSED against an endless stream of sky and trees. The train speeds up and SARA's face flies by, disappearing FROM FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: DUSK
dialogues.text: A zaftig BLACK WOMAN clumsily negotiates the aisle. Stops at the first of a few empty seats left in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This seat taken?

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: looking up, around. She shakes her head, clears her backpack and magazines from the seat beside her. The Woman drops down, settles in. A long silence. The Woman glances at the American Ballet magazine on Sara's lap. Tries to make conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love ballet. Never had the body for it. Do you dance? Sara folds her arms, turns away mumbling under breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to. Sara gazes out the window. The world outside begins to dissolve melting into images from another time, another place. Her eyes stare blankly OUT AT us, blinded by her memories.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: A stage full of five-year-olds in tights and tutus. A little girl performs center stage. She's remarkably poised, remarkably good. CAMERA PANS TO the audience. A woman in an Irish clover necklace springs to her feet clapping loudly. The little girl's eyes catch the glint of the necklace's gold. Mommy. She flashes a megawatt smile, ends the dance with an unscripted bow, as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Sara, lithe and earnest, dances. A budding beauty blessed with long limbs and natural grace, she makes it look easy. Gliding past the envious stares of classmates, she scans the hall for a glint of gold. Finds it in the back of the room where her mother, Glynn, stands watching her. Their eyes connect with mutual smiles and those smiles CARRY us TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of flexing feet in ballet slippers on a hardwood floor. PAN UP and PULL BACK to reveal Sara at 17, dancing in the space opened up by cornered furniture and rolled up rugs. As Glynn looks on, Sara completes the routine with a pirouette. She spins out of it with a preoccupied frown on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?   It was good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checks her stance in mirror)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody there's going to be good, Mom. I have to be better. (then, beginning again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My knees still knock when I do my free form. Did you notice that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I noticed that it was fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (escalating frustration)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not supposed to be fine. It's supposed to be special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it just lays there, it doesn't do anything. I bet they notice that. That it doesn't do anything. That I don't do anything special enough to get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara.   You'll get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't lie because you love me.     My free form sucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving up that battle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got something for you. Come on. Sit. Mouth closed, eyes shut. No pouting. No peeking. Sara flops down on the sofa beside her. Closes her eyes. Glynn removes the clover chain from her neck, fastens it around Sara's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For luck tomorrow. Not that you'll need it. You dance like an angel. The necklace is Glynn's talisman. Sara knows what it means to her. She throws her arms around Glynn, holds onto her tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love the necklace but you're still the best luck I'll ever have. Glynn, not one to choke up, chokes up.        They cling each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the blink of her eyes, the memory fades. She pulls the window shade, shifts in her seat. Her fingers travel to the clover necklace at her throat. Linger. The Woman regards her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice... the necklace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. It's a good luck charm. Doesn't always work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Woman's wearing a crucifix.     She indicates it. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine either.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: A sea of young white faces. A jock entertains the troops with two straws up his nose. Sara sits next to her best friend, LINDSAY, 17. Lindsay, chomping on a wad of gum, turns from the jock to Sara with a bubble in bloom, bursts it with her teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna pray? You're leaving for Philly after first period. I won't see you. We should pray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stupefied) Lindsay... no. Not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lindsay grabs Sara's hand and bows her head.      Sara, embarrassed, aligns her head with Lindsay's.      She's praying nobody sees them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Awesome, Father, S.J. auditions today. She's ready for them. Please make them ready for her. Even if she screws up. Thanks. Amen.' (sure shrug; another bubble) God's gotten me outta all kinds of shit. He oughta be able to get you into Juilliard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara exits with a bouquet of roses, takes the steps two and three at a time. Glynn's waiting in a flower van at the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara and Glynn. The back of the van is filled with flower arrangements. Glynn takes note of the roses in Sara's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you get those, traitor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellison -- Mr. Ellison. He actually told me to break a leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roses from the principal, even droopy, out-of-season yellow ones, is beyond cool, kiddo. You're definitely movin' up in the world. Sara looks through the windshield.   It's starting to drizzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what would be great? If you didn't drop me off at the bus station. If we just kept going until we get to Philly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ruin everyone's Valentine's Day and not have a shop when I get back. That's your definition of great? I can see the headline now: 'Starving Artist Kills Unfit Mother.' (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, we talked about this. I'll get there as soon as I can. Sara looks at her and Glynn instantly feels guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. This is the hardest, most important day of my life and all you can do is get there as soon as you can. Thanks, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS ACTION
dialogues.text: Glynn pulls the van into the parking lot. Smiles at Sara. Sara doesn't smile back. She's too angry. Too scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I guess I'll see you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't miss your audition, Sara. I'll be there, okay? If I have to swim the Susquehanna, I'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swim?   You can't swim, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll float then. A moment. They look at each other. Sara finally smiles. They embrace and she hops out the van. Glynn calls after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... Happy Valentine's Day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feigning sleep. From the corner of her eye, she watches the Woman beside her flip through the American Ballet Magazine. We move back in time through their pages.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: Sara, in costume, flips through a magazine. She taps her toes, checks her watch. A phalanx of parents and dancers are clustered around a sign posted on the door: JUILLIARD SCHOOL OF DANCE AUDITIONS. Sara stares at it. Re-checks her watch. An official with a clipboard walks toward her. Where's her mother?

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Sara on stage. She looks past a row of Juilliard JUDGES into the audience. No glint of gold. MOZART'S "Elvira Madigan" (Andante) CUES UP. Sara begins her technical. She transforms her nervousness into a notable, powerful performance. The Judges are mutely but clearly impressed. One of them looks directly at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything you'd like to share about your free form before you begin? A motif... a theme?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara's stomach drops to her feet. Her mother's not there and her free form sucks and she doesn't have a theme. Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's um, pretty self- explanatory. The theme.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judges exchange a look. New MUSIC CUES UP. Some driving, CLASSICAL NUMBER.   Sara tries to elevate her body above the music, but she's nervous, unsure on her feet. She keeps glancing in the back of the auditorium for Glynn. Searching for her port in the storm. Wondering where her mother is and knowing how badly she's dancing. Knowing but somehow continuing, stumbling, recovering, and finally finishing with those damned knocking knees. The Judges, eyes like stones, perfunctorily nod. Their equivalent of maybe next year. Sara chokes two words out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Rushes backstage. Fighting tears, she hurries past waiting dancers angrily unhooking the clover leaf chain from her neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara in street clothes. Cramming her ballet gear into a duffle bag when the official (of the clipboard) approaches her. She touches Sara's shoulder gently. Says something we do not hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING THROUGH office window. A state trooper in a rain slicker offers Sara a chair. She sits. The trooper talks. As he does, dread and disbelief spread over Sara's face. She shakes her head, attempts to stand. Her legs buckle beneath her. The trooper and the official catch her as she falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glowing moon in a clear, star-specked sky.

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN
dialogues.text: CHUGS toward Baltimore's Penn Station, which is visible in the f.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A torrential rain. A flower van -- Glynn's van -- caught in it. SHOOTING THROUGH the driver's side window, we can see Glynn's face, intense and determined, squinting through the downpour.

dialogues.speaker: VAN'S WHEELS
dialogues.text: Hydro-planing, slip-sliding.

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN
dialogues.text: It's SQUEAL OF BRAKES as it maneuvers into the station.

dialogues.speaker: VAN
dialogues.text: The SQUEAL of its BRAKES as Glynn loses control and smashes into the back of the eighteen wheeler in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN
dialogues.text: across space and time, the SOUND OF SQUEALING BRAKES commingle as the Amtrak Commuter pulls into Penn Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara. Holding her breath, clenching her fists. Waiting for the sound to stop, oblivious to the stare of the Woman beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROY JOHNSON, 37, a handsome, laconic man of uncertain style, takes a last drag from his cigarette, drops and stomps it. Passengers disembark from the train. Roy searches their faces. They all look like strangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A conductor helps Sara to the platform. Steam from the train's engine is sucked into the fog. She walks through it. Sees him. They see each other. Roy weakly waves. Walks toward her. Sara watches his bow legs stiffly advance. She wants to run. Can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a good ride? Sara self-consciously tucks her hair behind an ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slept through most of it. A beat.   Roy looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess you got stuff.    Baggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two suitcases.     One big one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like they're unloading. -- You hungry? We can stop somewhere if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm kinda tired. Roy takes her backpack.     They walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A heavy silence. Roy starts to turn on the radio, stops himself. He lights a cigarette, cracks the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't like leavin' you so soon after the funeral. I wouldn't have if you hadn't asked me to go. I mean, I could've hung around. Helped you say good-bye. That's what you were doin', wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy takes another drag, nods thoughtfully to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I figured you were doin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara peers out    the windshield. Baltimore City. The neighborhoods    are changing. The streets are getting progressively    gritty and dirty. It surprises her. It worries her.     Roy worries her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. Sara. I feel bad too. I mean, we both got hit by the same bolt of lightning. You don't have to pretend this is easy. (off nothing) Everything's upside down right now but don't worry. We'll work this bachelor-father thing out. Hell, it ain't like we're movin' in with strangers. We got a pretty good idea about each other, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara looks askance at him, her expression indicating otherwise. A moment. Roy's too new at this to hold up both ends of the conversation. The silence deepens. Roy switches on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's truck pulls up to a string of disrepaired rowhouses with pristine white marble steps. He and Sara each lug a suitcase from the truck. Her eyes wander up and down the street. They're on the fringes of a ghetto. A few people roost on their stoops, hang on the corners. All of them have black faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought you were moving to Fells Point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fell through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second floor of a two-story house has been turned into a one-bedroom studio. A partition separates the living area from the bedroom. Sara walks past a collection of saxophones and several framed pictures of herself. Aside from the saxophones and the pictures, there's hardly any furniture. Roy lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much of what you're used to. But the water's hot and the fridge is full. And I made room in the closets for you. Girl's gotta have closets, right? You even get your own bed. I'll crash on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bought a bed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slight bow)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me. Your own futon.     Check it out. On the other side. Suitcase in hand, Sara walks around the partition. Her "room" is an old futon, an ancient set of drawers. She stands in the middle of nothing, wanting something to do. She removes framed photos of Glynn from her backpack, places them around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara walks in.   Doesn't see Roy.   Calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a phone? Roy emerges from the bathroom drying his hands, walks past her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I have a phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't at the last place.    The last place I saw anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things change. You've changed. You grew up on me. Overnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the summer. You blew me off for some gig on the road, remember? (before he can respond) Can I call Lindsay? Let her know I got here alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright, Sara? (off the scowl in her eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanna know how you feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel fine.     I feel like calling Lindsay. She's a wall. A brick wall. Roy's head aches from knocking into it. He goes to the couch. Drops down. Mutters at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone's in the kitchen.   Knock yourself out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara lying in bed... wide awake... her stiff upper lip quivering. She slips out of bed, creeps on tiptoes into the bathroom. Closes the door oh-so-quietly behind her. She flips on the light, crosses to the sink, turns on both faucets. As the water flows and the PIPES RATTLE, the brick wall shatters. Sara crumbles to the floor. Buries her head in her arms. Cries like a baby.

dialogues.speaker: NEXT MORNING
dialogues.text: Roy and Sara. Barreling through the south end, tongues stuck in gear. A Pop-Tart grows cold on Sara's lap. Then, finally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can take the school bus. Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School bus? That's the other Oz, Dorothy. Patterson kids ride the city Metro. Or walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I know how to do both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not around here you don't. Not until you get the hang of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara looks out the window at a full-fledged ghetto. It's all to obvious, the hang of things. Roy glances over at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called about your transcripts. You're all set. Patterson's got a pretty good Humanities program. No ballet, but we can find a studio someplace close for after school --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I don't think I'll have time. I have to study, I'll be busy. Roy can hear the lie behind her words.      The pain too. lights a cigarette, cracks the window.      He wants to s the right thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea. Take a break. Not too long a break though. You're a dancer. You should dance. Stay on top of your art.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you stay on top of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I ain't playin' no grand ballrooms or fancy jazz festivals, but I'm playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unconvincingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean it like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S'alright. Hell, I wish I had half the time I wasted gettin' wasted. But those days are over. You'll see. I got my life on track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Formidably large and surprisingly well-kept, Patterson serves the nearby, predominantly black O'Donnell Heights Projects. Kids malinger outside on the front steps and lawn.

dialogues.speaker: PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: Roy's pickup pulls in. Roy CUTS the ENGINE. Sara looks at him. Or through him. She won't let his eyes connect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to go in with me. Since I'm all set. I mean, I have done this before. Gone to school. I'll be fine. I am fine. Really. Roy regards her with weary resignation.   Sara climbs out He calls after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Pick you up. Three-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over a shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Sure. Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara moving TOWARD us PAST a floating mosaic of black faces. This is a near out-of-body experience for her. She walks like a well-rehearsed soldier in a stiff straight line to the school's entrance. It's clogged with students. Inside the doorway, two security guards flank a metal detector. When it's Sara's turn to pass through, one of the guards grabs her backpack and wordlessly begins searching it. He hands it back to her on the other side of the detector where Sara stands obtusely and mutely amazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THROUGH a window, Sara seated across from an ADMINISTRATOR. We PUSH IN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It's no fun being uprooted in the middle of your senior year. We realize that and we'll do what we can to help with the transition.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: There's a KNOCK at door. MRS. GWYNN, the Guidance Counselor, steps in. The Administrator introduces her to Sara. Sara regards Mrs. Gwynn with polite petulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any questions?     Concerns?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About school?     No.   Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even about Baltimore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna be here that long. Besides, it's just a city, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gwynn looks at her squarely. But the brick wall doesn't move an inch. Sara feels too safe behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clutching new textbooks, Sara starts down the hallway. She's hoping nothing in her face reveals the rising panic in her heart. She's surrounded. Alone. Every inch of her feels afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as she MOVES FORWARD. A crush of KIDS -- mostly black with a sprinkling of white and Latino faces thrown in. Kids like her. Only they don't dress like her. They dress like commercials for Tommy Hilfiger and Calvin Klein. And they definitely don't sound like her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, man, check it, the muthafuckers wasn't playin', they was jackin'. Ten rides in five days. For real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fools got caught for real too. Ten years in five days. Stall that shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara walks on, taking this netherworld in, eavesdropping on other conversations. It's not just the words. It's how they say them: Loud. Matter-of-fact. Cool. A cooler cool. Like they breathe static electricity.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: That's it! The entire student body is energized. Sara's thoughts are jolted by two black girls squeezing by. One clips Sara's elbow as she passes, knocking it against a locker. They keep going as if they don't see her. No one seems to see her. Welcome to mass avoidance at Patterson High.

dialogues.speaker: AT SARA'S LOCKER
dialogues.text: Sara's back is to a black girl striding purposefully toward her. CHENILLE -- tall, pretty, with about a million braids in her hair -- swoops Sara's backpack from the floor. Thrusts it at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how easy it is to give to charity around here. Don't put your shit on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cautions a smile) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes her locker, starts to say something else. She's eager to make a friend. One friend. But Chenille's gone.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Sara memorizes the schedule of classes in her hand. She passes a clutch of students who surround a kid in the middle like a horseshoe. Sara gets a fleeting glimpse of him.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK REYNOLDS
dialogues.text: Eye candy: Tall. Dark. Heartbreakingly handsome. If Patterson were a monarchy, Patrick would be king. He sure holds court like one, turning on his dazzling smile and abundant charm for the crowd. One gets the sense that the All-American Home Boy is almost as enraptured with himself as the sycophants around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room's seen better days. Probably better teachers too. MR. JURASINSKI looks out at his American Literature class and sees nothing but tenure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Cold Blood    represents a turning point in our    country's literature. Take the cap    off and tell me why that is, Mr.    Ricard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDER to include the class. FAVOR "SNOOKIE" RICARD. We recognize him from the hallway kids wrapped up in Patrick. Snookie, a flagrant Patrick wannabe, sits next to him now. He removes his baseball cap. Thoughtfully twirls it on a finger. He truly believes he's being profound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gay rights. That Compote dude who wrote it? Sweet tooth. Straight- up fag, Mr. J.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Ricard. Your genius grant is in the mail. Anyone else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No volunteers. Jurasinski looks for someone to put on the spot. Sees the new girl in a back corner. Johnson. He gets into her line of sight. The class shifts in their seats, peeping her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms... Johnson. You can catch up later. If this is over your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks at her.        The way kids look at new ki

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a non-fiction novel. The first of its kind. Capote mixed true events with things he couldn't know, so he made them up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small murmur goes up.        Over this, the voice of a dissenter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White folks back then felt safe. Capote scared 'em. He took hard core crime out the ghetto and dropped it in America's back yard. That's what makes the book special.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sara cranes to see him. God. It's pretty-boy. He's sitting on the other side of the classroom. Looking... pretty. Looking at her. He has nice eyes. Not that she noticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   That is part of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all of it. Capote wasn't first. Richard Wright and James Baldwin did the same thing. Wasn't nobody tryin' to read them though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of people read them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A defensive save.      Patrick sees right through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of people like who?      You? Hello. Didn't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. J.! Girl needs to bone up. Give her a pass to the lib'ary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room erupts in laughter.

dialogues.speaker: ON SARA
dialogues.text: flushed in the face.      Embarrassed.     Pissed. ANGLE WIDENS as Jurasinski quiets the class.           Th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can have your pass, Mr. Ricard. Since you obviously never use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunchtime. PICK UP Sara among a cattle drive of boisterous students.

dialogues.speaker: CAFETERIA
dialogues.text: Hundreds of voices unleashed in pure, unadulterated teenage cacophony. Sara's in a queue of kids, working her way down the line.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She's as invisible and anonymous as ever. CAMERA TRACKS her FROM the line, TO the cashier, INTO the heart of the dining hall. She stands with a food tray, looking for a place to sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Table cliques of the cafeteria.

dialogues.speaker: JOCK TABLE
dialogues.text: Two tables pushed together.    Full.

dialogues.speaker: NERD TABLE
dialogues.text: Barely, pathetically populated but surprisingly diverse.

dialogues.speaker: HIP-HOP TABLE
dialogues.text: Loud, overflowing, fun.    King Patrick and his loyal subjects horse around.

dialogues.speaker: POPULAR TABLE
dialogues.text: Over which a glacial beauty we will come to know as NIKKI DAVIS presides. Girls only.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE TABLE
dialogues.text: Notable for its glaring absence of color.    A girl we wi come to know as TONI sits there. And then PUSHING IN ON --

dialogues.speaker: CHENILLE'S TABLE
dialogues.text: She's there with a group of girls who eschew pretense. They, like Chenille, are rugged and regular. They know who they are. END OF SERIES OF SWEEPING SHOTS.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: eyeing Chenille's table. Screwing up courage as she approaches it. She gets there but two black girls are faster. They sit down in the only empty seats. Sara backs off, invisible again.

dialogues.speaker: ON CHENILLE
dialogues.text: glimpsing Sara from the corner of her eye as Sara walks away.

dialogues.speaker: AT NERDS' TABLE
dialogues.text: Time has    passed. The cafeteria is half as full, half a noisy.     Sara sits among the NERDS, a friendly if verbo group.     She's trying to eat but a snooze button is talking    her to death...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I know you're new to the table, but think about it. We're the Y2K generation and nobody takes us seriously. We don't take ourselves seriously. Just look around. Half the student body is D.O.A. -- and that's from the neck up, Clara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara.   It's Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's Sara. And you're boring her from the ears down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara looks up, surprised to see Chenille standing there. She flashes a knowing smile at her, indicates Sara's tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You finished?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara leaps up with a quick, grateful nod. Beats a hasty retreat from the table. As she and Chenille walk through the cafeteria, Sara shudders with relief. She feels rescued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God!    Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Gotta watch where you sit, girl. And it's Chenille. But you're still welcome. Let's catch some air before the bell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara follows Chenille into the "QUAD," four squared off sections outside the cafeteria. There are a few dry- rotted picnic tables scattered around. Other kids -- and they run the gamut -- are seen in clots, sneaking smokes... horsing around... making out.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS OF QUAD
dialogues.text: And OVER the sound of HIP-HOP MUSIC, a pair of feet. Moving. Dancing. CAMERA PANS UP to reveal Nikki. She's demonstrating some moves to the girls from the popular table. Nikki's dancing her ass off, showing off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it called? What she's doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a look; knows that) No, I mean... the step, the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She trails off as she catches someone in the corner of her eye. She turns away from Chenille, gradually focusing on --

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: playing cards with Snookie at one of the picnic tables. He glances up to see Sara. Glowering at him. He grins. Sara rolls her eyes, turns away.      Mutters loudly to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Asshole beaucoup. In this crowd, you gotta be more specific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covertly indicates Patrick)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in one of my classes. Thinks he's so... smart. So cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about cute but he is smart. Real smart. Real trip, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick Reynolds? Hell yeah, I know him. He's my brother. Chenille waits for Sara to swallow her tongue.     Enjoys laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Nikki approaches him. Sexy, standoffish and conceited, she's the stuff of wet dreams and futile longing. She sits down next to Patrick. Close to him. Snookie watches her, much amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You comin' tonight? Patrick keeps playing his hand.     Responds very coolly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already skipped three meetings. (as he's ignoring her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it because of me? Everybody on the committee thinks it's because of me. Us. (infuriated by his silence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Patrick. Regardless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in charge of the music. I'm in charge of the prom. So show up. Don't make me fire your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fighting words. Snookie holds his breath. Patrick throws out a card, turns slowly to Nikki with a withering stare in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already fired my ass, Nikki. Once and done. Over. Out. 'Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stalks off. Snookie oogles her departure, peers at Patrick, about to say something. Patrick cuts him off, indicates cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit me and shut the hell up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'ma shut up... after I say it been real frigid 'round here since y'all broke up. 'Specially since she broke up with you. That was harsh, way she canceled your ass like a stamp for that Howard U dude. But their shit's over. Now might be the time to forget mistakes that was made. Shoot. You been with the girl since ninth grade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you sweatin' me, Snookie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pounding his heart) 'Cause I'm about you, man. I want a happy ending. Aww, shit. Tuck an' duck. Here he comes. The hood of the 'hood, up to no good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MALAKAI RHINEHART, 17, heading toward them. Powerfully built and edgy with insolence, Malakai is like a tightly- wound coil -- you never know when he's going to snap. ANGLE WIDENS and we see Patrick is happy to see him. He and Malakai grin at each other. Knock handshakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medicine man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interjecting himself) Did I tell you, Malakai, man, how chill it is to have you back? We ain't been bad without cha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up and step your lame ass off, Snookie. You heard me. Space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snookie haughtily, comedically obliges.        A moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to you at lunch, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Short-hand. Patrick understands it, nods. Malakai slips the cigarette from behind his ear, openly lights and starts smoking it. CAMERA TRACKS them walking back toward Patterson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're hangin' in, man? Feelin' strong about being back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at this motherfucker. Out a week and where am I? Fucking home sweet high school. Jail away from jail. You can have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna stay though.   Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge says it's school or JuVee and I sure as hell ain't goin' back there. Shit. I never knew a year could be such a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flash of commiseration, of guilt, crosses Patrick's face. They're at the doors now. Most of the kids have gone. Malakai puts his cigarette out on the floor as they step in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You up for some hoops after school? Break your free-throw back in. Chump the chumps like we used to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up for it? Hell-the-fuck yeah, man. Let's do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara exits with Chenille. A CAR HORN starts to blare. Both of them ignore it. But it goes on like a musical number. Sara gets a sinking feeling that drops like a stone when she looks across the street. Roy's parked at the curb, waiting for her. She rolls her eyes and he HONKS AGAIN. Then he waves at her. Waves! Chenille looks at Sara. Then at Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your old man? Now he's cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Yeah.   He is. For you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara climbs in, slams the door. Roy looks over at her, unaware of how annoyed she is with him. She's a clenched fist inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd it go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. (as he pulls off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow I catch the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara's moving the partition around, trying to make her room more like a room. Trying to build another wall between her and Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Sara.   C'mere a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara lets out a heavy sigh.        What does he want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just come here. She walks into the kitchen. Roy's in front of the open freezer door. Grinning from ear to ear. He motions her over. Sara crosses to the freezer. Looks inside.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE FREEZER
dialogues.text: It's full of frozen dinners.       They're in unruly, lop stacks.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Roy regards her expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungry and Healthys. I asked at the market. They're the best. So. What do you feel like? (whimsically) Lamb Chop Suey? Tropical Tuna? Primavera Paradise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a big lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, deflated, closes the freezer door, trails her into the living area. Sara's clenching again. There's no escaping him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you wanna do? You wanna hang out with me? Go to my gig. You can if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a school night, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.   School night.    Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's gone. Sara takes her first good look around. A mess. It drives home where she is. What she's lost. It's overwhelming. 59   INT. ROY'S APARTMENT - KITCHEN - CLOSE ON EMPTY T.V.

dialogues.speaker: DINNER TRAY
dialogues.text: An empty beer bottle, one askew kitchen chair. Vestiges of Roy's meal. ANGLE WIDENS as Sara enters. She opens the freezer to unearth a dinner and starts an avalanche of falling food. A box of Sugar Puffs cereal lands at her feet. Something else out of place. She picks it up, jams everything back into the freezer. Slams the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: in a whirlwind, cleaning the apartment. Wall to wall. Scrubbing away what's churned up inside. The dervish ends in her "room," where she finishes unpacking. Several layers into a suitcase, she comes to her ballet shoes. The sight hits her like a slap in the face. Sara stares at the shoes until her eyes blur. Then she snatches them up and entombs them deep inside her closet.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: Patrick, Chenille, Snookie straggle through the dreary jungle of concrete lawns and blighted high rises on the way to school. It's quiet now but the scars of past battles, like the bombed out police substation on one of its corners, are evident everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a date --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?   Your hand busy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- For the prom. And if it wasn't for that kinda undue attitude, you could be the lucky girl, Chenille. My personal prom queen. I can see us now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be lookin' in your dreams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snookie glances at Patrick.       He's somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me, man.    Defend me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got my own problems, Snook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What problems? You goin' to college. Doctor college after that. You large, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't gonna be doctor nothin' if I don't get in and I'm not in 'til I get my letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in the mail, Patrick.       Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wishfully thinking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I probably coulda been a doctor too. If I hadn't got left back that time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That time? What? Fifth and sixth grade don't count? Patrick finally laughs. Then his face changes. Becomes serious. He hops a low wall, keeps in stride above them. They continue on like this, the ruins of their world in the b.g. behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus is crammed with kids. Sara, seated by a window, doesn't bother looking out. Inside's more interesting. The kids cut up. Singing, rapping, and jousting with each other. Some even manage to read. Sara watches with immunity. She's invisible to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara alights just as Patrick, Chenille, and Snookie walk past. Patrick's the only one to see her and their eyes briefly connect.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS ACTION
dialogues.text: Patrick and Chenille pass through metal detectors, watch Snookie clown his way through. The security guard shakes his head. All three begin to walk. Snookie, bobbing and jiving, doesn't see Mrs. Gwynn coming up from behind. Her voice stops him cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Patrick and Chenille look on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light on your feet? Good. Be sure they dance into my office next week. She moseys on.   Snookie regards Patrick's smile, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class has donned lab coats and is ready   to begin wh Sarah rushes in. She tries to slink into a    seat. The teacher, MR. HILL, gives her a disapproving   look, point at one of several formulas (C2,H6,O2) on the   blackboard Sara just looks at him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're cooking today, Ms. Johnson. This is your first lab. You'll need a partner. Mr. Reynolds -- Patrick -- will show you the ropes. Patrick bounces a smile off unsettled Sara.     This shou be fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class, in safety goggles and gloves, has partnered up.

dialogues.speaker: SARA AND PATRICK
dialogues.text: He's holding two vials. Sara picks up a beaker. Stares at the blackboard. She has no idea -- and no intention of admitting it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very casually)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too big. She glints at him, grits through her teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's too big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts the beaker down. Picks up a vial. Flips through her textbook. Her eyes shift from it to the blackboard, trying to make a connection. She settles on one. Picks up a vial of powder. Patrick grabs her hand, leans over and whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't do that if I were you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yanks her hand back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who died and made you teacher? Patrick pulls back, looks at her. He can't believe she dissed him. A small smile forms on his face. Sara turns away from it, goes back to her vials. Patrick slides to the farthest end of the table. Watches her consternation with bemusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know the difference between ethyl glycol and methyl acetate? Both got three elements, two parts the same. It's that first part, C2 versus C3. C3 could blow a vial right out a person's hand. Sara thinks he's messing with her. But then the contents of the beaker begin to ominously bubble. Panicked, she drops the vial into their sink. It instantly goes up in smoke. Some of the liquid splashes on Sara's lab coat. Patrick grabs a wet towel, quickly wipes it off. The class stops cold. Hill rushes up to them. Once he's sure Sara's fine, he looks sternly at Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?      Everybody back in your seats! Patrick stares at Sara.     Her face is red.     She's bi her lip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I misread the component.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (even more angry now) You? You misread a component. Don't give me that, Patrick. You were screwin' around!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hill's tone is searing. He turns to     Sara. She's tryin to say something but the words won't    come out. Hill regards her wearily, then walks off    pushing the curiou class back to their stations. Sara     looks at Patrick, weakly mouths "thanks."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the sound of GRUNTING... OPEN CLOSE ON a girl's plump ass. Squirming in too-tight gym shorts that hug the cheeks. ANGLE WIDENS to reveal a stout white girl on a balance beam. Trying to get her legs to stand up on it. Hanging on for dear life. From somewhere around her, a WHISTLE BLOWS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, Ms. Diggs. Time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDEN to see the teacher and her class (FAVOR Sara, Chenille, and Nikki). Amid snickers, the stout girl ("DIGGY") slides off the beam, walks past the teacher with her head demurely cast down. Clearing the teacher, Diggy pivots around, both middle fingers in the air. Gives up the double bird with much attitude. The class loves it. Cheers it. Until the teacher swerves around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille on balance beam.    competent but average. Nikki on balance beam.    Agile.   Self-assured.   Good. ... And then TIGHTER STILL on Sara. Tentatively approaching the balance beam. Mindful of all the eyes on her, all the bated breaths. All waiting to see the new girl fall on her ass. Sara swings herself onto the beam with aplomb. Her legs and body are strong, supple, pliable rubber bands. She flounces across it on her tiptoes. Does a flawless split. Hops off. Looks out.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER AND CLASS
dialogues.text: Reacting with shock and surprise. Awed. Except for Nikki. She stands there with her arms folded. Simmering. Envious.

dialogues.speaker: PATTERSON HIGH
dialogues.text: Sara. Heading down the steps with other students. Chenille and Diggy break through the logjam, catch up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girl, how you get your legs to twist like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wildly gesticulating) Yeah. What was all that double- jointed cheerleader shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Diggy.     Thinks she's down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Egg-cuse me?     I am down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Sara.   What's up with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awkwardly) Nothing's up with it. I used to kind of dance. Ballet. Mostly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille makes an impressed face.          Regards Sara curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should hit Feetz with us tomorrow night. It's a club. Sorta members only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Un-der-ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on and hang out. Snook dee's sometime. He can get you in. (yelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, Snook Sara sees Snookie... then Patrick... loping her way. She steels herself. He's going to say something, crack some joke about her nearly blowing him up. But Patrick just stares at her with a twinkle in his eyes. A nice twinkle. Sara's not entirely immune to it. Chenille breaks their eye play, pushes Patrick aside. She grabs Snookie's arm, indicates Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She needs to get hooked up for Feetz. All the way up. Sara, give Snook twenty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I.D. Eye-dee. How you think you gettin' in? On your looks? (rolling his eyes) Chenille, your girl is weak. Shit. I got my rep to watch. I can't just be gettin' any green in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara glares.     Regards Snookie with a sweeping scowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look closer. And if I still look green, I think maybe you should wipe the crust from your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snookie's jaw drops. Patrick cracks up. Diggy too. Chenille's stays on point. She's about solving the problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna pay the man or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ain't got it. Look at her. Loud-talkin' me and broke as a damn promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara, put on the spot, pulls out the money.     Snookie snatches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even know where it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we'll hook up at my house. Go together. I will have your I.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snookie shrugs affirmatively. Patrick looks directly at Sara. The twinkle in his eye is gone, replaced by fair warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feetz ain't no square dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay. I dance in circles. Probably around you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy walks in to see Sara on the futon in her pajamas reading a book. She's got a head full of rollers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm splittin'. (as she barely looks up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha readin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chemistry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're takin' chemistry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now it's taking me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give yourself some time. Well. See ya in the mornin'. Maybe I'll call between sets. Sara really looks up.   Gives him an angelic, sluggish shrug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be asleep. He leaves. As soon as Sara hears the front DOOR CLOSE, she jumps up, strips down to bra and panties, races to the closet. One hand rips the rollers from her hair, the other rips through outfits. She's frantic and unsure about choosing the right one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara. In a skin-tight miniskirt and a bolero jacket. Looking more eighties than nineties, more cute than cool. She walks with tentative, jittery purpose down this poverty stricken street. Doesn't meet anyone's eye. But can feel the eyes on her. She keeps going. She's walked too far to turn back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Approaching the malignant edifices as the Heights begin to come to life... or death, depending how luck's running. Sara walks into this world of shadows and despite a trepidation, finds something fascinating about the possibility of real danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille triple unlocks the door, lets Sara in. Sara's surprised -- the apartment is surprisingly quaint and extremely neat. It looks a helluva lot better than Roy's place. Chenille is dressed in hugely baggy military- style pants and a tube top with a form-fitting, short-cut leather coat over it. Sara takes it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool outfit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slammin'.   Slammin' outfit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I look okay? Chenille gives her the once over.   Decides to lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  You look okay. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moma Dean. I'm leavin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDMOMMA DEAN enters with a toddler ("CHRISTOPHER") in her arms. She sports snow white, waist-length dreads and she's wearing a dashiki lounger. Despite her white locks, she doesn't look old enough to be a grandmother. She hands Christopher to Chenille. Inspects Sara. Her eyes are open, kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fussing over Christopher)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandmom, Sara. Sara, Grandmom. Also known as Momma Dean. And handsome here is Christopher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Now don't get him all riled up, Chenille. I want to get some sleep tonight. Chenille kisses Christopher, hands him off to Momma Dean. They exit. Sara looks tentatively at Chenille.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that... is he... yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sure ain't Momma Dean's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've been talking.   Well, Chenille has. Sara's been listening. Intently.    Liking this confidence they're sharing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... He'll be one in July. Best mistake I ever made. Kenny -- Christopher's father -- he's the worst. Triflin'. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A curbed cab. Sara and Chenille get out. Chenille digs into her pocketbook, hands Sara her I.D. PUSH IN ON photo of obese white girl with an untamed trailer trash perm. Sara's eyes go wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille.   She's ugly.   She's fat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's twenty-one too. I ain't got all night. Let's hop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. I have to ask you something. (hard for her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I really look alright? An unspoken thing passes between them. Chenille suddenly whips off her coat. Gestures at Sara with her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme that '89 Madonna shit.    Your jacket. Give it here. Sara takes off the bolero. Chenille ties it around her own neck, then yanks Sara's miniskirt down around her hips. Sara's torso is clad in a long-sleeved cotton tee. Chenille frowns at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's from the GAP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's country. You look country in it. Take it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not walking in there in my bra.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Chenille thrusts her leather coat at her. Sara can't believe what she's doing, getting (un)dressed on a public street! She pulls off the tee, slips on Chenille's coat. Buttons it as far as the buttons go. Looks down. Half her chest is exposed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gaining on what looks like an abandoned warehouse. Chenille snorts at the roped off queue of kids waiting to get inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rope dopes.   C'mon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads Sara to the door of FEETZ. The Sumo-sized MAN guarding it knows Chenille, digs her. His grin exposes gold-capped teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille.    Lookin' fine.   As always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too fine to stand in line? The Man grins, opens the rope, lets them in -- "in" being just inside the front door. A BOUNCER there collects the $10.00 cover charge. Checks their I.D. He hands Sara's back with a smirk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Changed your hair. He waves a metal detector over their bodies, nods to yet another bouncer who escorts Sara and Chenille through yet another door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They march a short distance to an old elevator where a group of kids wait. Bouncer #2 engages the elevator. Everyone piles in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara holds onto her stomach as the CREAKY ELEVATOR descends and the MUSIC below rises. The elevator's vibrating with music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an inside to Chenille) Can't get much more underground than this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smoky hole in the wall, filled to the brim with kids. Mostly black kids with a few whites and Latinos melting in. They share a common goal: To clog the dance floor, flaunt their outfits and get nasty with the music of the masters: Tupac Shakur, NAS, Lauryn Hill, Puff Daddy, etc. Here, the boundaries of dirty dancing are pushed, from erotic to vulgar; loving to lascivious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara and Chenille. Sara's excited. She loves that she has to shout to be head over the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get our table 'fore it gets crashed and I hafta hurt somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara's bewildered. She doesn't see any tables. She follows Chenille to the back of FEETZ. Sees six or seven tables. All of them have reserved signs. Most of them are filled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you, some kind of V.I.P.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille indicates the deejay booth.     Snookie's in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snook hooks me up whenever he dees. They walk past a SLACKER in lycra pants and a big Army shirt. He licks his tongue at Chenille, grabs at her protruding butt. She swirls around, grabs his crotch hard enough to get his attention. The Slacker is squirming in her clutch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw'right, aw'right. You got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he can't think of anything but the squeeze on his balls) The right to walk past your greasy, tickle dick self without your paws on my ass? 'S'that how I got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille bobs her head right in his face. Sara can't believe it. A few people have stopped and are looking. The Slacker nods hastily. Chenille releases him, gently smoothes out his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how I thought I had it. (a fly wave) See ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She and Sara continue on to back-of-the-club tables. Stop at a reserved one. An adjacent table sports Nikki, her three girl crew... and Diggy. All nurse drinks. Nikki snake-eyes Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is up with this place? Seems like they're lettin' anybody in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   And they started with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three girls and Diggy snicker. Nikki gives Chenille a look. Turns back to Sara with a snide smirk. Points out her crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Nikki. Alyssa. Jasmin. Tiff'nee. You know Diggy, right, Marsha?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara. It's Sara. And I know you. We have a class together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That don't mean you know me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit it, Nikki.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit what? I ain't walkin' on eggshells just 'cause you brought the Brady Bunch to the Negro Club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kiss-my-ass polite) Maybe you came to the wrong spot, Nikki. I'm pretty sure this one doesn't have any Negroes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille cracks up mainly to back Sara up.       Nikki gl at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pretty sure you came with one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. Uh-uh, wench. You did not just call me a Negro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Chenille bucks, Diggy springs up from her seat, runs her arm in the space between Chenille and Nikki like a referee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, y'all. Chill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her to chill. She always got somethin' to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can say a lot more. Keep runnin' your mouth, Nikki. I'll lay all your shit bare. Whatever shit it is, Nikki's not taking any       chances ejects herself from the table, walks off.        The thre girls scoot loyally after her. Diggy gets        up. Sits at Sara's and Chenille's table. Diggy goes        with th flow. That's why she always fits in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you burn her like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I can't stand her ass and the way she played my brother. I need a drink, Sara. Let's walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick and Malakai enter with two high school dropouts we will learn are ARVEL and LIP. Females flock to flirt with Patrick and Malakai, who both swell like sponges, soaking up the attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille pushes her way to the bar, tugging Sara along. A tall, angular twenty-something MAN on the far side of the bar sees her. She sees him. Sucks her teeth, nudges Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him.        Comin' over.   Kenny? Don't look. So of course Sara does. She makes a silly face at Chenille as Kenny sidles up to her. Chenille rolls her eyes half-heartedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my money, Kenny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little short this week. Don't jump off. It's comin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's comin'?    No. You lyin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme rap to you about the situation on the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes her head firmly but her eyes do tell. She's in love with him. Enough to let him whisper in her ear, sweet-talk her away from the bar. Before she's swallowed up by the crowd, Chenille turns back to Sara, shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rum and Coke.    No ice.   Hook me up.

dialogues.speaker: ON PATRICK
dialogues.text: splitting off from Malakai and a girl clinging to him. He's walking through when Nikki appears from nowhere, grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling away) Let's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?   It's gonna be like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you think it was gonna be? That you was gonna drop me and pick me up whenever you felt like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't all that serious, Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't anymore, Nikki.     Not to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks off. CAMERA TRACKS him going deep inside the club. He wants a drink. He's almost at the bar when he sees Chenille on the dance floor with Kenny. She shrugs a smile, then cocks her head over at the bar. Toward Sara. The look is like, help me out. Don't let me leave her hangin'. Patrick rolls his eyes as he glances at Sara, before he really sees her. She looks fly. Hugely fly. He ambles up as she shouts into the bartender's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rum and Coke, straight up. And a beer. I don't care. Anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad choice.      'Anything.' The closeness of his voice startles her. She turns into his smile. That cocksure, leave'em-weak-in-the-knees smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it should be the best beer. You'd know that if you really drank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara's knees straighten, her spine stiffens.         The asshole's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that mean? Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you want it to mean. You're the whiz kid, right? You know everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckles at this, at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not everything. Like I don't know why we're standin' still. (closer with a teasing whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to be dizzy by now. Remember? From all those circles you danced around me. Sara leans against the bar.    The knees are going again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel like dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you do know how...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would I be here if I didn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Let's do it then.    C'mon. He coaxes her onto the dance floor. PARLIAMENT'S funk classic "Flashlight" is playing. The dance crowd is robustly singing the refrain to the song. There's a party on the floor. FAVOR Sara and Patrick, facing each other. He's moving already. She starts to dance, stiffly, tentatively. Patrick smiles at her. Shakes his head. He grabs her hands, swings them in time to the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now move your hips. Not so fast. (as Sara looks lost)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara! Just like our hands. (singing, in sync with the crowd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Flashlight! Neon light! Stop light! Everybody got a little light under the sun.' The music's beginning to feel good to Sara. Patrick lets go of her hands. Starts to dance. Sara watches him intensely, her body follows his stiffly. Patrick's a good teacher. He leads without leaving her. Whenever she misses a complicated move, he smoothly segues into another less-complicated one.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sara begins to pick-up on Patrick's rhythm. Her eyes never wander from his. And then she starts to feel something else. They both do. A rising beat. A quickening heart. And not from the dancing. She smiles bashfully at him. Patrick suddenly grabs her around the waist, pulls her to him in a sexy spoon dance. All Sara can do is try to keep up and hang on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki avidly watching Sara and Patrick with Jasmin and Tiff'ny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's all up in your nut, Nikki... Oh, that's right. It ain't your nut anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is if I want it to be. He is if I want him to be. That bitch ain't got shit on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls regard her in conspicuous, dubious silence. Nikki maintains her cool but inside her pride is pricking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malakai and the clinging girl nuzzle in a back corner. She licks his ear, whispers into it. Malakai laughs. Then his expression abruptly darkens. A storm cloud comes over it. He gets up.

dialogues.speaker: WALKING TOWARD
dialogues.text: ... two dealers a few feet away. They're talking to an Asian guy with a multi-colored Mohawk. One slips Mohawk a packet of coke, the other takes his money. WIDER as Malakai reaches the dealers. He doesn't explain, doesn't complain. He just starts swinging.

dialogues.speaker: SARA AND PATRICK
dialogues.text: The MUSIC changes and their dance ends. They stand there for a moment, a little caught up in each other. A little unsure of the moment. And then there's a scream! Several of them actually. Patrick reacts to it instinctively. Looking around. In a small pocket of the club he sees Malakai.

dialogues.speaker: MALAKAI
dialogues.text: in full fisticuffs with the two dealers.     Holding his own.

dialogues.speaker: ON PATRICK
dialogues.text: leaving Sara, slicing through a clot of looky-loos until he reaches Malakai. He jumps into the fray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thick crowd around them, proceed to beat the living shit out of the two dealers.

dialogues.speaker: SARA AND CHENILLE
dialogues.text: wrangling their way to the front line of the crowd, Diggy not far behind them. Sara looks on, dumbfounded and dazzled by what she sees, which is --

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK
dialogues.text: pummeling his dealer into cowering submission. Only then does he look over at Malakai who, eyes engorged with rage, is standing over his opponent, kicking and stomping him with no signs of letting up. Patrick can see Malakai's too far gone for talk. He rushes him from behind, nearly lifts Malakai off his feet to swing him away from the dealer's writhing body on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The exit door bursts open and Patrick and Malakai tumble out. Patrick bends over, cups his knees as he catches his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, what the hell are you doin'? Tryin' to get sent back up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They the ones tryin' shit. Comin' here. Squarin' off in my shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You couldn't let it slide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let it slide tonight, they come back strong tomorrow. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malakai, you fuck up parole, you ain't gonna back to JuVee. Eighteen and up, that's Jessup. Hardcore lockdown. You want that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (regards him coldly) I want what was mine. Feetz is my spot. I'ma do business here just like I did before. Like we did before. And if I gotta stomp some niggers in my way, so be it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An uncertain but tense moment.     Patrick tries to salva it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you definitely got the stompin' part down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other.     Share a small laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We fucked those fools up for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crossing to exit door) For damn sure, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick finds the door locked. He and Malakai hoist themselves over a high, wrought iron fence. Disappear behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Distant WAIL of SIRENS as Feetz begins to empty out. Kids converge on the sidewalks. PICK UP Sara, Chenille and Diggy. Waiting and watching for Patrick. Diggy looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about to get real out here. Cops and shit. I'm gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves. Chenille spots Patrick. Not too worse for the wear. She smiles with relief. Then Sara sees him. She smiles too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara, Patrick and Chenille. Walking home. Chenille's preaching to Patrick. He's not in the mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Yeah, I'ma tell you. Tell you like I keep tellin' you, Patrick. You need to let Malakai alone. Let him handle his own shit before he drags you down in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille. I heard you the first five hundred times. They round a corner bordering the Heights. Stop in front of it. Chenille, disconcerted with Patrick, looks dourly at Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you Monday. (to Patrick, like an order)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll walk you. As much as this makes sense, it still takes Patrick by surprise. Sara sees it in his face, regards Chenille with a false bravado.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a few blocks.   It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not okay. Would you tell the girl it ain't okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not okay, okay? (before she can protest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Braveheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: walking.   Sara keeps stealing glances of him.   Or so sh thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (caught)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you keep lookin' at me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to look somewhere. The streets are deserted. Might as well look at you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not why. You wanna know somethin'. Ask somethin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a question. It's the way you were beating that kid up. You looked so mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was mad and he wasn't no kid. But you're from the suburb Mars, right? Folks don't fight there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not like that. (some kind of wonder) You were really kicking his ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not funny, the look on her face.      But Patrick laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you laughing at me? Dropping the smile, Patrick shakes his head.      Looks a her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend was in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's my question. Your friend. Chenille doesn't like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She likes him. It don't stop her from trippin' off him now and then. But Malakai's good people. We go back. Way back. You know, like they say, through thick and thin. (beat) So, how'd you like Feetz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once you got used to the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't the music I wasn't used to. I mean, it's not the first time I heard hip-hop, Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Bet you listen to it all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick regards her with a sly, knowing smile. His stare is significant, unsettling. Sara's face flushes. She turns from him, hoping he didn't see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not all the time. But a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gettin' any closer to your crib or should we stop for food and water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara snaps out of it. Looks around. Shit. First the flush and now this. She looks at him. She could kick herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We passed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You passed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look. They double back to her front door.        Pause the stoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for walking me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So.      I'll see ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that 'see ya' like gee-whiz, had a great time, can't wait to see you again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or is it like 'see ya,' I'll bust a cap in your ass if you ever darken my doorstep again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes it impossible not to smile.     So damned charmi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't said gee-whiz since I was six. But I really had a great time... okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She enters the rowhouse. Patrick waits until the lights go on inside before he turns around and starts home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's making breakfast when Sara straggles in. She peers at the stove. Scrambled eggs and bacon. Toast too! A first for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figured I'd put a little marrow in your bones. Siddown, siddown. (she slumps in chair) You gettin' along at school? Makin' friends...? (as she nods robotically) ... See any of 'em last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slides a plate in front of her.      Stands there hold his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came home on my break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The succinct sneer in her voice gets to Roy.       He sna her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Oh? Jesus! You're hard! Look. You're seventeen. If you wanna go out, go out. But don't lie to me. On top of everything else, don't make me worry like that about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after long moment) I didn't mean to yell. (sits down; trying like hell) So how are the eggs? They good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara takes a small, tasteless sample, nods. They eat in silence. Then Sara looks over at him with genuine if detached remorse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. I should've said something. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy exhales.     Finally, a chink in the brick wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you gonna do today? Anything special?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.     Nothing special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A track from TOP DOGG BLARES from invisible SPEAKERS. All of the store's many customers are teenage kids. Snookie, in sunglasses and a reversed baseball cap, clerks behind the counter. He's ringing up (and trying to rap to) a fly girl when Patrick walks in, overhears the overture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... How   you   know I can't do nothin'   for   you? I'm the hardest workin'   man   in showbizness, girl. C'mon.    Let   me be the bomb in your shell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fly girl rolls her eyes. Takes her bag. Leaves. Patrick looks at Snookie, wryly shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do the shit to yourself, man. The bomb in your shell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was black magic, Patrick. It's gonna work one of these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches behind the counter, hands Patrick a Jay-Z C.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last one on the rack. I snatched it up for you. Rang it up on my discount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (what Snookie's waiting for) Thank you, Snookie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Patrick pays him) You workin' or what, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On my way.   Soon as I get outta here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he says this, his eyes wander around the store.      A he sees her in the stacks. Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
