dialogues.text: Sara with a bunch of C.D.'s. She juggles them in one hand, flips through Hip-Hop C.D.'s with another. She looks up to see Patrick standing beside her. He takes in the C.D.'s. Grins at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throwin' a party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no wiggle room but Sara wiggles anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just adding to my collection. I heard some stuff I didn't have last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (that twinkle in his eyes) Well, you were fly anyway. Last night. Dancin', I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as fly as you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half-serious) Nobody's as fly as me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dead-serious) Not yet anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick laughs. Looks at her.        Sara looks back at h They're staring at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we could hook up later. After school or somethin'. Work on some of your moves. If you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick nods affirmatively. Starts to leave.       Turns back, indicates her stack of C.D.'s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, Hammer's pretty much played out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (convincing lie) Not to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara's on the phone, unwrapping one of those T.V. dinners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) It was so... slamming, Lindsay. The dancing! I'm going again. What? No, I haven't seen anybody get shot yet. God, I didn't move to Bosnia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fight. Two black girls having at it. It's a ferocious match. Hair pulling, spit flying, punches landed, clothes torn apart.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: as she crowns the corner, comes to a bottleneck of students. It's like the nose bleed section of Caesar's Palace. The far hallway is the ring. Sara cranes her neck to see the action.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ANGLE WIDENS as a security guard earns his hazard pay. He separates the two girls who are still swinging at each other. He throws one into a corner, hurls the other in an opposite corner.

dialogues.speaker: ON SARA
dialogues.text: as a WHITE GIRL standing next to her shakes her head lamentably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The White Girl studies Sara's suburban clothes and fresh- scrubbed face. Thinks she found a kindred spirit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We freed the slaves and didn't teach them no manners. (before Sara can react) You're Sara, right? (as Sara warily nods) Toni. I was gonna introduce myself before but you're always with that crowd. You know. Chenille, her girls, that identity crisis Diggy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara looks at Toni. Getting it. Getting her. The expression on her face closes off. Toni, too dense to read it, keeps talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightly) We should hang out sometime, Sara. The two of us. Whenever you decide to lose the tan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her inference clear, Toni flashes a brilliant smile, happily walks off. Sara shakes her head to herself. What an idiot. As Sara continues down the hall, a P.A. address comes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seniors, a reminder before you rise up and change the world. Mrs. Gwynn is holding all diplomas hostage in her office. Her only demand is the pleasure of your company for career D-Day. Be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara enters her classroom, a bunch of kids in front of and behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara walks up the street (passing many black people), sees Roys' pickup. Shit. He's home.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA TRACKS
dialogues.text: Sara as she enters their rowhouse, walks up a flight of stairs to their apartment. There's a JAZZ INSTRUMENTAL FAINTLY coming from it. And another NOISE. Foreign and yet familiar. Like grunting... but not. Sara unlocks the door. Opens it.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Her father's fucking somebody! On the couch. Half on it anyway. In broad daylight! The whore underneath him is moaning. Jesus! ANGLE WIDENS as Sara turns away from the spectacle. Reaches for Roy's sax. She blows the longest, shrillest note known to mankind.

dialogues.speaker: ON ROY
dialogues.text: The hair on his head stands up.    His body deflates instantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara sits at the table. Roy enters in a wrinkled T-shirt and battered jeans. His embarrassment is naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what to say.    I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout fuck it? Or should I say fuck her? It's a fuck-fest, Roy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk to    me like that, Sara. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you    were goin' to your friend's house    after school. Obviously, you    changed your mind. So I'm sorry.     Alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry you got caught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I got... observed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "whore" with the Hich C is RHONDA. She stands between the living area and the kitchen entrance now. Sara tries not to look at her. Can't help it. She has to see the whore. Not bad looking, in a washed out, bottle blonde barfly kind of way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be mad at him. It's my fault. I'm real sorry, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nobody's 'fault.' It's over. Let it be over. We're all adults.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara glares at him.     The disingenuous Rhonda jumps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he means you know about sex. That we have it and he likes it. Isn't that what you mean, Roy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara looks at her.     Bats her eyes.   Hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?   How often do you have it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things been kind of slow since you got here. Once upon a time we were real rabbits, weren't we, Roy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Verbal quicksand.      Roy can feel himself sinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rhonda.   Shut up.   Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPEN CLOSE ON a framed photo of Glynn and Sara (in full ballet costume). Embracing. Happy. PULL BACK to see Sara. Sitting on the edge of her futon, holding Glynn's clover leaf necklace and staring at her mother's face. Lost. Lonely. Missing her. She kisses the lucky charm, smiles at Glynn, slips the necklace on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick, in coveralls, slouches over a mechanic's station studying. A few workers mill about, waiting for the next car on a slow day. A BMW with tinted windows peels into the lot on two wheels. Patrick looks up as Malakai and a tall, wiry, nattily dressed man get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it. He exits into the lot.    Approaches Malakai and the man ("TUTE").

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medicine Man.     You know Tute. Tute takes in Patrick.    Looks around.   Snickers derisively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call this a job, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I call it a car wash. The work I do, yeah, that's a job. Malakai lets out a nervous laugh.     Tute doesn't crack smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need some sticks.    Watch my ride, Malakai. Tute enters the cashier's office.    Patrick looks at Malakai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hangin' with him now?    Think that's a good idea, 'Kai?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a better one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could try layin' all this shit off for awhile. Give yourself a chance on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What other side?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I mean. It ain't like you don't have good sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got sense enough to know who I am, what I can do and where I can do it. I ain't like you. People don't just up and hand me shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tute emerges from cashier's office lighting a cigarette from a fresh pack. He blows a plume of smoke into the air, regards Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ain't here for our health.     You workin', then work. (throws Patrick car keys)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't forget the rims.

dialogues.speaker: LATE THAT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Patrick, still in work coveralls, enters. First thing he does is pick up a stack of mail. Tracking him into kitchen as he crosses to refrigerator, takes out a plate Momma Dean's left for him. He sits down at the table, takes a breath, begins shifting through the mail. His face registers disappointment. Nothing. Again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick sits across from Mrs. Gwynn, the reality check of Patterson High.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you think it's enough to have the grades, get a full scholarship. But it isn't, Patrick. Georgetown makes mulch of students like you every semester. You have to be ready to change. Change friends. Lifestyle. Your entire point of view. What I'm saying is, options won't matter if you don't keep a clean nose to the grindstone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks her right in the eye)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that, Mrs. Gwynn. The unflappable Patrick.    He doesn't fool Mrs. Gwynn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knowing's easy. Doing is hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in which a series of STUDENTS parade in front of Mrs. Gwynn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? I wanna operate on cars. Some place fly like the Kentucky Derby. -- Ah-ha! Joke on you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Career?   That the same as a job...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Rock-n-Rap club in L.A. I'm gonna put a tattoo parlor on the roof. Soon as I find some investors...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be a lawyer, but I believe in God so I'm not sure about it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm moving to Idaho.      I hate it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beauty school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a year behind 'cause of my baby, but I'm gonna work during the day, go to school at night. That's my plan anyway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plans? Yeah. I plan not to be poor. Next question...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get into U.M.B.C., financial aid, everything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I detect a 'but'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki folds her arms, regards her obdurately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're -- how do you put it? -- Large here, Nikki. You enjoy that and it's fine for now. I guess. But you can't live your life like a popularity contest.

dialogues.speaker: ENDS WITH SARA
dialogues.text: walking in.     Sitting down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it's realistic, what you're asking. Things happen. Things change. And the changes change you. What's the point of plans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To have a sense of direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't direct destiny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fingering Sara's papers) I see here that you trained for Juilliard, that you auditioned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was three months ago, Sara. (the brick wall)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you're not going to pursue dance, what are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hadn't thought about it) I don't know. Take a year off. Work. Go to college later on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful with later on, Sara. It's a slippery slope. Sometimes you can run right on top of it and it never catches up with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A low sun over the cityscape of Baltimore. PUSH IN ON Patrick and Sara, two dots that grow larger. He CLICKS ON a BOOM-BOX resting on the roof's ledge. A hip-hop track BLASTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feel the groove. Don't let the music mess with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to move with the music. Sara tries to emulate him. They dance throughout the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you always want to be a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said I wanna be a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille.   Everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cinches her waist, pushes in her ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it tight.     Watch your butt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of doctor do you want to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pediatrics. I like kids.         Come on, stay with me. You're slackin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any? Kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't being smart, Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't be the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops.     Regards him.      He stops.    Regards her Stalemate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screw you.      I'm brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes into a spin, a half-split, comes out of it swaggering and half-stepping around her. Sara gives him an impish look. Rises up on full pointe, turns out her legs and lifts one of them in a spiral just below his head. It happens in two blinks. So fast Patrick thinks it was a mirage. He stares at her, dumbfounded. Sara smiles. The look on his face is worth the pain in her joints. She blows some stray hair out of her face, puts her hands on her hips. Looks appropriately hapless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get it. That thing you just did. Show me again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that shit you just did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He mimes the move -- badly.        Sara can't help it. laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A releve.    Over ice.     With a twist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (succumbs to his bewilderment) Ballet. I used to dance, Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You used to dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Used to as in don't any more. And don't ask me why. She sounds suddenly defensive.       Patrick's suddenly intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I don't want to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why you brought it up. Did that whole relieve thing. 'Cause you don't wanna talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's not a big deal.       Can we just concentrate on this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we can concentrate. (a beat; goading her a little)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I think it is a big deal. Whatever it is you don't wanna talk about. Sara shakes her head adamantly. He nods his head emphatically. Another stalemate. They dance coyly, seductively around it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara. Doing stretching exercises as she talks on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still gonna pray for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Sara, you're in the freaking ghetto. Forget the riots. How are you supposed to meet anybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara slides down the wall, hugs her knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have met somebody. Sort of.       I think. I mean, there's this guy...

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Patrick enters to hear CHRISTOPHER SCREAMING his lungs out. He passes down the hall to Chenille's room to find Christopher squirming in Kenny's arms. Kenny doesn't know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking in) What y'all doin' to my nephew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick takes Christopher, holds him and consoles him until he settles down. Patrick pointedly hands the baby to Chenille, glares accusingly at her and Kenny as he quits the room. Kenny regards his son haplessly. Looks at Chenille.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's he do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a baby.   They cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was screaming, Chenille.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't know you, Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm his father. He knows me. (meaning now) ... What should I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come around more often.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?    I can't talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I can't depend on you! Am I askin' you to do anything for him you ain't supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't ask, Chenille. You make demands. You want money, you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I want you to pick up some of the slack. You always have an excuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not like that.    I get tied up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna talk about tied up? Try gettin' up in the middle of the night to change diapers and give him bottles or stayin' up with him when he's sick and havin' to drag your ass to school the next day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look.    I'm doin' the best I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't good enough, Kenny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dripping, out-of-order faucets, graffiti-laced stalls, litter-strewn floors are underscored by the spooky flicker of fluorescent lights. Sara walks in. The bathroom appears to be empty. She's about to enter a stall when she hears the murmur of a voice. A guy's voice. Then a girl's whimper. She eases forward a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get paid 'til next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boo the fuck hoo. You can't put my bizness up your nose on no layaway plan. C'mon now. You know what you gotta do.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sara ventures carefully forward to the edge of the stall's open door. She cranes her neck trying to see without being sen.

dialogues.speaker: STALL
dialogues.text: A GIRL is seated on the toilet. A man straddles her, his crotch in her face. The Girl sees Sara. Something in her face gives this away. The "man" glances out past his shoulder. He looks right down our throat straight into Sara's eyes. Malakai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malakai backs up. The Girl jumps up, runs out the lavatory. Malakai zips up his pants. Sara's frozen, staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't see nothin', you don't say nothin'. Not unless you want a taste for yourself. And that can be arranged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves.     Sara waits a moment.   Exits.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: She sees Mr. Hill, starts to move for him. Someone grabs her arm from behind. She turns, startled, a little afraid. It's the Girl from the stall. She looks Sara in the eye. Shakes her head. Don't. Mr. Hill walks by them unbeckoned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A perfect day. CAMERA PANS FROM the waterfront TO the bustling crowds of the inner harbor, then to a park across from this where Sara and Patrick are practicing. HIP-HOP MUSIC softly PLAYS from Patrick's BOOM-BOX. Sara watches his face as they dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you like it when you 'used' to dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah I liked it. I was gonna go to Juilliard. That school fucked up my entire life. It's a long story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me guess. You don't wanna talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara looks at him.     A soft smile is all she offers up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lay on their bellies in the grass.       Close to ea other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stole a bike here once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I didn't have one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to do wild shit like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Malakai?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.   Most of the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get you guys.    You seem so... different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you weren't then but you are now. You said you changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't make me different from him. Not the way you think it does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Malakai's scary.   And I know you're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking mild umbrage) What you mean by scary? 'Kai's tough. He has to be. He still got a good heart. I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara stares at the ground, struggling to tell him what she saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me finish. Me and him got into some shit awhile back. Real bad shit. We held up a gas station off 95. I bailed the ride -- jumped out the car. 'Kai kept goin', got caught. (pauses) I knew what he was gonna do that night. Knew the car was hot. I woulda been guilty as him if they had caught me, if Malakai had served my name up. But he didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That means you owe him something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did his time plus most of mine. I owe him that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No matter how much he messes up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all mess up. Maybe Malakai gave up. But he's still m'boy and he still got a chance. I ain't just gonna cross him completely off and be like everybody else. He looks at her and she doesn't have the heart -- or the nerve -- to tell him. A long moment. She plucks a dandelion from the grass, twirls it thoughtfully in her fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stole a hat once. When I was twelve. My mom found it under my mattress, made me take it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gangsta' Sara.     Stole a hat.   Call the F.B.I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him.       Smiles.   Twirls the dandelion un his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna turn me in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll wait for you to surrender. (pauses) Were you tight with your mom, Sara? I mean, y'all get along and shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (guardedly) Yeah...tight... got along and shit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So she meant something to you. How come you never talk about her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying her face) Know why there's nothing to say? Because you don't talk about her. You won't talk about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry she's dead. God! What do you want me to do? Run through the streets screaming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?    If it helps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tersely) Well, it won't. So drop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you call Malakai scary.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks at him. Patrick grins. Sara knocks her legs against his. He knocks his legs back. A silly moment. But it transcends the tension and creates a sweet truce between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momma Dean's fixing dinner. Patrick enters with the mail in his teeth, a load of books in his arms. He dumps the books on the counter, busses Momma Dean's check on the way to the 'fridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're not puttin' those dirty hands inside my refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick  backs up to the sink. Washes his hands. Impishly  dries them on her apron. He sits, begins sifting  through the mail. Momma Dean pulls an envelope from her  pocket. Waves it at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This what you're lookin' for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille appears in the doorway. Patrick takes the letter. He's almost afraid to open it. But he does. And as he reads the letter, a slyly relieved smile spreads across his face. He tosses the letter in the air. Grabs Chenille and Momma Dean. And the three of them jump up and down together with joy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dressed to the nines. They look happy and relaxed, more so than we've ever seen. They sit close to each other. Very close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you gonna tell me where we're going? (as he grins, shakes his head) Why is the surprise for me? You're the one with something to celebrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can celebrate together.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks at him. Can't find any words. So she just goes into her evening bag and pulls out a small box. She hands it to him, a little nervous about how it will be received.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to get you something and I couldn't figure out what. It's not much but I hope you like it. Patrick opens the box. Removes a key chain. It's engraved with the medical emblem (snake & staff, etc. He regards her, touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it.   I love it.    Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.     There's more. She leans in, turns the key chain over in his hand. The back side of it is engraved with the words, "PATRICK REYNOLDS, M.D." Patrick locks eyes with Sara, lifts her hand to his lips. Kisses it softly. The gesture is succinct but alluring and, for a brief moment, they're the only two people in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus makes a stop and an older white woman gets on. Sits across from Sara and Patrick who have moved even closer to each other. Patrick's arm is around Sara's shoulder. He whispers something in Sara's ear. She laughs and looks up to see the white woman staring at them with a muted but obvious repugnance. Watching the woman from the corner of her eye, Sara drapes her arms around Patrick's neck, nuzzles at his ear. Patrick's eyes widen. Sara, playing this for all it's worth, folds one of her legs between his and whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have an audience.      Work with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nonplussed) Work with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce, through her teeth) Grab something.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He grabs her ass   -- what else is there? -- runs his han along her side.    The white woman, thoroughly disgusted, gets up and moves   to the back of the bus. Patrick and Sara look at each   other, burst out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The equivalent of D.C.'s Kennedy Center, the hall is awash in lights and activity. Men and women are donned in formal attire. Parking valets hover on the sidewalks waiting for cars. Into this, Sara and Patrick walk. She looks at the crowd, then sees the overhead banner -- "Boston Ballet, A Command Performance." Sara's heart stops. Her feet freeze. Patrick looks at her. She looks positively catatonic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprise... Sara?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly urgent) I can't. I can't go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't understand) You have to go in. This is where I'm bringing you. The ballet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beside herself) I know, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crestfallen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what? Sara looks at him, feeling bad. Feeling stupid for ruining the evening. She bites her lip, shakes her head ("but nothing"). Patrick takes her and they go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara and Patrick watch the Boston Company perform Igor Stravinsky's "Scenes De Ballet" as choreographed by Christopher Wheeldon. They're both enraptured. But while Patrick keeps sneaking excited glimpses of Sara, her eyes remain fixed on the dancers, the dance. She is utterly, totally engaged and amazed. The yearning that never really left her returns to tug at her heart and project her soul onto the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Post-ballet, Sara and Patrick walk. She's quiet, introspective. Patrick's at a loss. He can't decipher her mood and, which is more, he's disappointed by it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you would like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't actin' like you did. She looks over at him, tries to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. They come to a small, secluded bridge.     Sara sits down the edge of it. Patrick follows suit.      A long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want you to think I didn't have a good time tonight, Patrick. I did. But ballet isn't a part of my life anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? What happened? You just woke up one day and decided to waste your talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without rancor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know I have talent? Because I did some stupid leg trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw the look on your face when you did it, Sara. The same look I saw tonight. Goofy happy. So if you're gonna tell me somethin' about not dancing, at least tell me somethin' real. A long, difficult moment wherein Sara attempts to find the words, face the pain that comes with them. Finally, she looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I don't want it to be real.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She stares out at the water, the moon reflected off of it. It's hard to reconcile that beauty and the turmoil she's feeling. But she goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I want is to wake up and see my mom. For things to go back to the way they were. When they made sense. When my life made sense. (because)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's all my fault. She got scraped off the highway for me, for my fucking audition. She was rushing. It was raining. It was raining... (a torrent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... But she promised to be there. I made her promise. And then I didn't wait for her. I should have but they called my name and I didn't say anything. I just went out and danced. I was mad. I needed her and she wasn't there. She buries her face in her hands, breaking down, racked with tears and guilt. Patrick puts his arms around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inconsolable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was dying while I was dancing and I was mad at her and I'm sorry. I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not your fault it rained or she died. Or that you danced. That's what you were there for. Your mom would've expected you to do what you did. Sara, choking on tears, regards him forlornly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what makes it so bad. She always did what was right for me. I wanted to be a prima ballerina -- had to be. Even if it took most of our money, all of her spare time. I didn't care. It was my stupid dream and it killed her. All she wanted was for it to come true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still got whatever you had when your mom was alive, Sara. She wouldn't want you to give up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara swipes at her face, looks up at him, still crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know... but she... I just don't think I can do it without her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding her) Do you want to do it, Sara? I mean you. Do you want Juilliard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it's on you to make the dream come true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   For my mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For her.   For you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick walks Sara to the front door. They pause on the stoop. Neither of them wants the night to end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rhetorical question under the circumstances. Patrick regards her tenderly, moves her hair from her eyes. Stares deeply into them. Sara smiles wanly, certain she looks like shit. But it doesn't matter. The moment has named itself. And so, with more certainty than passion, they kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS the room, PICKING UP small touches from Sara's past life, her previous bedroom -- more on display than we've seen before. HOLD ON closet door. A beat before Sara emerges from behind it, ballet slippers in hand. She takes a deep breath. Slides them on. Peers down at her feet. Wiggles them. Nothing magical or mystical but simply wonderful. Gleefully wonderful. Like the end of a long day's journey to home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara and Patrick negotiate the heavy pedestrian traffic, exit the complex. He leads her to a mall of trees and bike paths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme see that move you did.     That cute leg relieve thing. (as she shakes her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hates to admit this)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hurts! I'm out of shape and it hurts. Okay? Satisfied?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (admiring her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what you call outta shape, what's it take to get you in shape?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the perfect spot for that. You can run around and I can sit under the trees and watch you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get in shape like that. But it's still a good spot. (diffidently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got my application for Juilliard. Just in time too. They're holding auditions in Baltimore next month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great! She looks at him, shakes her head.   Not that great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never be ready in a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara, you puttin' the mojo on yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a smile in spite of herself) Mojo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Negative shit. White folks call it karma. The bad kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand. Ballet takes a lot of time, a lot of preparation. I used to practice two, three hours every day. I'm so far behind... ... And unsure and afraid. Which Patrick can sense. he won't let her go there or stay there. He's firm, matter-of-fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit whinin' and catch up then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not as easy as that. My free form still sucks. It's still the weakest part of my routine. That hasn't changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I'll help you with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised that she's surprised) Yeah. I'll help you. Tell me what you need to do and let's get busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara in the mirror dressed in leotards and tights. bends forward from the hip, extends a leg, a corresponding arm.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As she tries to complete the arabesque, the backward-most leg buckles. She steadies herself. Starts over.

dialogues.speaker: PATTERSON FOOTBALL FIELD
dialogues.text: Hip-hop hybrid with Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE STUDIO
dialogues.text: In class.    Struggling to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: On way to and from bus stop.    Practicing as she walks.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE STUDIO
dialogues.text: Alone with her instructor.    Looking good.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE STUDIO
dialogues.text: Alone with her instructor.    Looking better.

dialogues.speaker: ROY'S BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Soaking and tending her bleeding feet. MONTAGE ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPEN CLOSE ON a black hand shaking a white one. PULL BACK to reveal Patrick and Roy. Sara enters looking striking, pretty, very down. Chenille's influence is written all over her makeup and her clothes. Overlooking Roy, she blithely tags Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's skip. (cursory, to Roy) Later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They leave. Roy stands in the middle of the room, dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's 'skip'? (mumbling to himself) Three months and she's skipping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Usual suspects, usual music. Patrick hands Sara a call- brand beer. Leans in with his drink, openly and contently with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki and her crew (Jasmin, Tiff'nee, Alyssa). Nikki hasn't seen Patrick and Sara. She's showing her crew a dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille, Diggy and another black girl.     Fraternizing.

dialogues.speaker: DEEJAY BOOTH
dialogues.text: A chrome-domed deejay with a Barry White baritone bellows into his mike as he changes the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master P with the 'Ghetto D'. Showmesomethin', showmesomethin', give up that cruel. Eyes on you! WIDER as the dance floor swells with kids. PICK UP Sara and Patrick among them. She looks at him nervously. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's watchin' you but me. A gallant lie. Sara tries    to believe it. They dance. Practice has made her near   perfect. Their movements are ambitious, nimble, better   than anyone else on the floor They move so well together   that Snookie, dancing nearby starts chanting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, Patrick!    Go, Patrick!

dialogues.speaker: DANCE FLOOR
dialogues.text: Diggy.     Jiggling and wildly gyrating.   Chiming in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, Sara!   Go, Sara!

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK AND SARA
dialogues.text: building up a sweat; confidently dancing at fever pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody have funk, funk, funk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara and Patrick, still going at it. Snookie, Diggy and others prance around them like backup dancers.

dialogues.speaker: NIKKI
dialogues.text: standing with her crew dourly observing Patrick and Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch me squash their shit.    Hard.

dialogues.speaker: ON NIKKI
dialogues.text: Shoving, pushing, and barging her way up to Patrick. Without preamble or regard for Sara, she starts dancing with him. Patrick looks at Sara but he's somehow dancing with Nikki. Sara retreats with daggers in her eyes. Pissed.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK, (AND NIKKI)
dialogues.text: unresponsive as she grinds her body into his, raw and wild.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: standing where she can see but can't be seen from the dance floor. From a curtain of kids, Malakai suddenly appears at her side. Sara can't move. She's boxed in. Malakai indicates Nikki and Patrick with slick satisfaction, whispers derisively:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't never gonna look as good as she does with him. That's oil. You're milk. Ain't no point in tryin' to mix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He evaporates into the crowd.        Sara stands there.

dialogues.speaker: PATRICK AND NIKKI
dialogues.text: as a SLOW DANCE BEGINS. Nikki starts to press herself against Patrick. Patrick holds her off with both arms. Walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: moving toward Sara. A stark, apologetic expression on his face. He takes her hand. Sara fiercely jerks away. Patrick grabs her hand again, more emphatically this time. But Sara won't budge from the spot where she's standing. So Patrick slides his arms around her, holds her without moving. They remain like this for a moment or two until they slowly begin to dance. We PUSH IN ON them in this little space. Patrick's lips brush Sara's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: slow dancing with his flavor of the night. Eyes on Sara and Patrick. Both underwhelmed and resentful of what he sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara unlocks the door. She and Patrick enter. She turns on the lights. Looks at him. Answers the unspoken question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in D.C. Blues Alley.   He'll be gone all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick sits down on the sofa. Sara crosses to the STEREO, turns it ON. A SAX SOLO begins playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's demo. The only one he ever cut. Kinda grows on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.   Somewhere between five seconds and forever. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna see my room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick looks at her, nods. He gets up, follows Sara behind the partition into her "room." They stand there for a moment. He cups her face with his hands. Kisses her. They begin to take off each other's clothes, alternately sure and fumbling; a bit awkward, a bit urgent. Sara unzips Patrick's pants, catches something other than his clothes. Patrick winces in pain. She looks at him with an embarrassed grimace. Says this very low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss again, stumble backward to her futon.       Fal down upon it and begin to make love.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: CAMERA TRACKS them as they walk down the hall hand-in- hand, sometimes exchanging greetings with other students. They are officially a couple and they appear to be in love. At the door to Sara's next class, Patrick busses her lips before she enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No teacher is present. The class files in. Toni drops down in a chair beside Sara. She leans over in a conspiratorial whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you do, don't fuck him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Hit it and quit it,' that's their motto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose motto?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black guys.    Everybody knows that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The teacher walks in.       Sara quickly whispers back to Toni.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget, they all have big dicks and beat their wives. Everybody knows that too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malakai, along with Snookie and two brain donors, ARVEL and LIP, eat at a booth. Patrick strolls in gritty from work. Tired from work. He slides in next to Malakai. The mood is light, jovial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You smell, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can a piece of shit tell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table cracks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been scarce lately, man. Where you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere dreamin' of a White Christmas...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And Christmas ain't even for 'nother six months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lip. It's a so-to-speak thang, you ignorant fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at Patrick) So.   So to speak? Whassup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snatching up one of his ribs) Back out my business, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching Patrick keenly) You tappin' that white girl, man? (half joking) That's why you ain't got time for your boyz no more, you too busy frontin'. Too busy snowflakin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick lifts one of Malakai's ribs, responds coolly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I frontin', 'Kai? I made time for this bullshit, didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aww, man. You busted. That's why your jaws are gettin' so tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the one need his jaws tightened with your pork-ass instigatin' self.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: Patrick's roving fingers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Order somethin', Patrick. This ain't no goddamn soup line. Patrick grabs some of Arvel's fries, chews them in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'all hangin' tonight or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We thinkin' about slidin' through that new rec center opened up on the Eastside. You ridin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eastside?   That's the wrong side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't messin' with those fools over there. You know how they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't pressed. I got my own shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shorthand. The table stops. Malakai glances around, lifts his shirt to expose a gun. Patrick stares at Malakai with disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you think? I'ma keep walkin' around waitin' for some chump to cap me? I'ma protect myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ain't protection. It's an excuse for some unnecessary mayhem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't nothin' unnecessary 'bout it. Shit. Mayhem and madness. That's a black man's life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you know? You ain't tried nothing else. Now you sittin' up here strapped for no good reason. You askin' for trouble, Malakai. (as Malakai laughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think this shit's funny? Snookie shifts uncomfortably. Arvel and Lip look at Malakai. Malakai looks at Patrick, coldly drops his smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's funny you think it ain't necessary. You act like you don't know where you are no more, Patrick, and whassup out there for anybody who ain't you. Maybe that's what happens when a white girl goes to your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Or gives you some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Lip. (looks at Malakai) I know what's out there. I also know you can get past it. But that ain't gonna happen, 'Kai, long as you keep gettin' in your own way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (peacemaker) Aw'ight. Y'all said what you had to say. We back to bein' boyz. Patrick. Chill. Have some ribs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara and Patrick, post-coital. She's in her robe. He's dressed but they're fooling around as they fix sandwiches. Patrick drops down in a chair. Sara drops down on his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your favorite flower?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a favorite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but if you did...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. Maybe cymbidiums -- orchids. They're sort of show- boaty but they're pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your favorite color?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agua.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your second favorite color?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm.    Mauve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're makin' this real hard, Sara. Those ain't exactly tuxedo colors.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sara swings her legs around, facing him, straddling him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nut.   What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was tryin' to get around to askin' you somethin' but since I'm some sorta nut, you probably wouldn't wanna go to prom with me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws her arms around his neck, kissing him. Patrick slides his hands under her robe, cups her breasts. Sara responds to him. They are too engrossed in this intimacy to hear the FRONT DOOR OPENING, to see Roy until he walks in and sees them. Sara leaps up, closes her robe. Patrick doesn't know what to do. He's caught. Straight up. Red-handed. Roy's eyes dart between them, settle on and slice into Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick -- it is Patrick, isn't it? (a small awkward nod) Well, I think you were just leavin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick stands up.      Sara grabs his arm defiantly, hol him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does he have to leave?   We're all adults. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He either leaves or I throw his ass out. Your call, Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick jerks his arm free from Sara, grabs his jacket off the back of his chair. He back-talks Roy as he passes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chill, man. I'm goin'. You don't have to come off with all 'at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you to tell me how to come off? You're in my house alone with my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: It takes everything Patrick has to keep walking until he's out the door. It slams behind him. Sara marches up to Roy, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate being your daughter.    You ruin everything. She tries to stomp off.    Roy kicks a chair in her path. Snarls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Siddown. (not a request; an order; as she sits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a free country, you can hate me. Ain't like that's exactly news. But disrespectin' me, that's where the road ends, Sara. I don't want him up here again. I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean it because he's black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't start that bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's it bullshit? Because you hang with black guys and play jazz and have the hots for Angela Bassett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he was in my house with his hands all over my daughter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep telling yourself that. Just don't expect me to believe it. I saw how you looked at him. But you didn't see him. Well, for your information, he's a straight- A student with more heart and guts than you'll ever have!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, when are you gonna have the guts to say what you really want to say to me, Sara?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming at him) Want me to say it? You were a piece of shit husband and you're a piece of shit father! You were never there for Mom or for me. You took off and never looked back. So don't talk to me about guts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not quite the truth, but near enough to sting. It quiets Roy down. He regards her with regret and guilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like you have it all figured out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have you figured out. You think you can make up all the time you missed, all the things you didn't do? You can't! I'm here because I have to be and it's a goddamned nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you might as well wake up and get used to it, Sara, because that's the way things are sometimes, the way life is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell would you know? You've been asleep for the past thirty-seven years! Now she does storm off. This time Roy lets her.     He can't find the words to deny what she's said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A break between classes draws the requisite claques and cliques. Sara and Patrick huddle over a chemistry book, attentive to each other. Nikki stands off watching both of them. Malakai saunters up to her smoking a joint. Hazily indicates Patrick and Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 'Love Boat.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love shit. That bitch is tap- dancin' on my last nerve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like she's tap-dancing on your last boyfriend. She got it like that? Naw. Never mind. Stall it. I ain't heard shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stall what?   What you hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some trash she's talkin'.   About you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. How you ain't all 'at since Patrick's takin' her to the prom. (in for the kill) I am a little bit... chagrined though, Nikki. You lettin' some white ho' show you up like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He regards her with bemused pity. Nikki, with all her inner outrage, manages to salvage her pride. She sneers in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Malakai. Fuck her too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gaily, a she sails off) Ain't no need in fuckin' me... stuck up, bitch... I'm on your side

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick drinks at a water fountain. Looks up. Malakai's standing there. There's still some tension between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo. Me and the boyz fixin' to shoot some hoops. Us against Druid Hill. If you interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Druid Hill?   Hell yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta skip last period.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got study hall. Don't matter anyway. Not with those suckers. I'll be back before the bell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk off together and, after a few steps, begin dribbling imaginary balls down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girls' basketball game in progress. Sara's playing defense. She's on Nikki's team. She blocks a shot but Chenille, on the opposing team, gets it on the rebound. Basket. Nikki shoots Sara a murderous look. Stupid, uncoordinated bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A four-on-four game in progress. Patrick, Malakai, Snookie and Arvel versus the Druid Hill Two Deuces. An unseen BOOM BOX BLASTS the music of JAY-Z throughout. Patrick has the ball. He passes it to Malakai. They AD- LIB insults to the Two Deuces. This is heaven for them. Talking shit and playing ball. The best time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara takes her defensive position against an opposing player, successfully blocks the shot, tries to slam the ball to Nikki. It clips Nikki's head, bounces out of bounds. Nikki, her dignity stunned, her patience out, walks up to Sara, shoves her to the floor. Sara looks up at her as some disembodied voice calls out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't start nothin', won't be nothin'! Stay down, girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malakai dribbles the ball around one of the Two Deuces, skies it. Misses the hoop. Patrick rebounds. Passes it back to 'Kai. He takes the shot. Makes it. Patrick and Arvel strut victoriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara jumps up, shoves Nikki back.    And the fight is on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the dejected Deuces look on, Malakai high-fives Patrick and Snookie. Arvel's moving into their circle when SHOTS RING OUT. Everybody on the court instantly dives to the ground for cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara and Nikki tumble to the gym floor. The surprise is Sara. She matches Nikki blow for blow. It's a punishing fight for both of them and it only ends when the gym teacher separates them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car speeds off. Patrick raises up, looks around. Malakai nods. He's okay. Snookie's crawling to the exit, snot-nosed and crying. He's okay. Then they see Arvel. Sprawled on the ground. Covered in blood. He seems lifeless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In adjacent chairs across from Mrs. Gwynn's empty one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a hiss, under her breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't over, bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over? I don't even know why it started... bitch. And don't say it's about Patrick because it's not. It's not about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's about you. White girls like you. Creepin' up, takin' our men. The whole world ain't enough. You gotta conquer ours too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like him, he likes me. And if you don't like that, screw you. Mrs. Gwynn walks in.   Sits down.    Looks reproachfully them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls.   I think you need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy's tuning his sax when Sara enters. Her face is a mess. Yet she drifts by, bruised and bent over, as if this were the norm. Roy does a double-take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got suspended. Two days. She straggles into her room.    Roy follows her to the futon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what? Fighting? (as she nods like "no shit Sherlock")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why were you fighting, Sara?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sardonically)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. I think it's some kind of black female thing. He sis down beside her, instinctively reaches out to touch her face, assess the damage. Sara sharply flinches away. But Roy persists and after a moment, she lets him minister to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick walks in, Arvel's dried blood stained into his clothes. Chenille's cooking with a sound-asleep Christopher slung over her shoulder. She and Patrick regard each other morosely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Arvel? Patrick slumps down at the kitchen table.     He's barely audible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty bad. (almost to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't even play a got-damned game of ball no more. Chenille comes up behind him.    Squeezes, pats his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see Sara? She alright? (as he looks up with a question mark) You didn't hear? Nikki jumped off at her in gym. It was fierce...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Given the day, this is the straw on Patrick's back. He bolts from the table and on his way out nearly bumps heads with Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick RINGS the DOORBELL. Sara opens the door slightly, just enough for Patrick to see her face.      I pisses him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright.    I'm okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy appears in the space behind her, looking out.      Sa can feel his presence. Her eyes implore Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look.  It's not a good time. (gently shutting the door) I'll see you later... I'm okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The laundromat is empty but for a few customers and Nikki. She's loading clothes from two large baskets into washers when her brother DIONDRE, 10, races in. He's grinning from ear-to-ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diondre, what your butt doin' here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a taunting twist)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can go where I want. You the one on punishment. Nikki swings a wet shirt with no intention of hitting him. She looks up. Patrick's standing in the doorway. Diondre runs up to him, holds out the palm of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There she go.    Gimme my two dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick pays him. Diondre darts out. Patrick walks up to Nikki. Nikki clenches, tries to dismiss him with a backhanded wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever it is, I don't wanna hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick leans up against a washing machine and for a long moment just looks at her. The walk there has composed his emotions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you had somethin' to say to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old black woman is avidly, openly watchin' them. Patrick indicates a bench on the other side of the laundromat. Nikki petulantly follows him there. They sit. Patrick looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somethin' must be on your mind for you to get up in Sara's face, start all this drama. What you tryin' to prove, Nikki?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the one tryin' to prove something. Stuck up in her shit like she's somethin' special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if she is? What's it to you? You didn't see me trippin' off that Howard dude and I could have. I coulda tripped hard, Nikki.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you gonna call it different?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands up.     Looks down at him.    Raises her voice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she's white and he ain't. And don't sit there like you don't know what I'm talkin' about, Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glaring at her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't even know what you're talkin' about, Nikki.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't?     Y'all black men, soon as you even    think about goin' someplace    good, first thing you do is find a    white girl to take with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick glares in the Old Woman's direction, then back at Nikki.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I was goin' someplace good with you. You the one called me off. But you ain't tryin' to remember that. Now you mad. Why? Because she's white and I like her? I'm with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. You're with her because she's white. That's what sets me off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) It ain't got no business settin' you off! Me and her ain't got nothin' to do with you and what you think. So keep your hands off her and that shit to yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikki folds her arms across her chest, looks at him defiantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it, I know it. But you go ahead, deny it. That's what y'all always do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns on her heels, goes back to her machine. Patrick rises, sees the old woman glinting at him. He holds her hateful stare for a moment, then walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille and Kenny.     In the middle of a contentious moment. He tries to     give her some money. She snatches it out of his hand.     Kenny looks at her. He's hurt. Chenille's too mad to    see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I'm supposed to get excited because you decided to skate by and drop a dollar on the dresser?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's more than a dollar. And it's all I got. (beat) I got laid off rom B.W.I., Chenille. I been workin' part- time. Money's tight. You know how you are about money. That's way I haven't been coming around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille stares at him for a long moment.       Her voice low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money ain't got nothin' to do with it, Kenny. You don't come around because you don't feel like comin' around. You don't want the responsibility of comin' around. As long as you out there and I'm in here, you know your son's being taken care of. You ain't got no worries when it comes to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you don't have no   feelings when it comes to me.    All you do is bitch and complain   about what I don't do. I get sick    of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be sick of it. You ain't got to see me to see your son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be sure to keep that in mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves.    Chenille stands there, mad at him.    Mad a herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lowest common denominator for misery.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The room is filled with young women, most them black, and children of all ages. They are piled up like cars on a freeway, waiting to be seen. The noise level is at a peak when Chenille and Sara walk in. Chenille's carrying a fussy Christopher, his diaper bag and her backpack. Sara, wanting to be helpful, reaches for Christopher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to take him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille shakes her head. Walks to reception to sign herself in. Sara takes in the faces of girls younger than herself, the grime and gloom of the room. It's incomprehensible that this is a place where sick children are brought to get well. Chenille finishes at the desk. Returns to Sara. They cross to a corner of the clinic where they sit -- on the floor. Chenille indicates the receptionist bitterly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wench. You gotta stand over her to make sure she puts your name on the damn list. Triflin' bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille starts to change Christopher's diaper. He starts to wail and flail. Chenille can't placate him. One of his kicks connects with Chenille's open backpack, sends books and papers flying. Sara can see the veins stand up on Chenille's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does. Chenille's finally got control of Christopher but he's still crying. Chenille slips off his dirty diaper. When Sara hands her a clean one, Chenille regards her strangely, as if just remembering that she's there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So your old man flipped about the fight. (with some animus) Probably thinks it's all Patrick's fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   I explained about Nikki.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. You put it all on her. None of it's on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She started it, Chenille. She wanted to start it. I told you what she said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chenille flashes a look, finishes up with Christopher. She picks him up, puts a bottle in his mouth. Cradles him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe she didn't have no business gettin' in your face. But she had a reason to say what she said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A reason?    Sara studies her, trying to fathom the remar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you agree with her? You think I don't belong with Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I think don't matter. But you and him act like it don't bother people that you're together. Like it don't hurt people to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her Irish up) We like each other. What is the big fucking deal? It's him and me. Not us and other 'people.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white girl with the rose-colored reasoning. Chenille glares at Sara, her voice designed to snatch the blinders off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black people, Sara. Black women. (passionately) Patrick's about somethin'. He's smart. He's motivated. He's for real. He ain't gonna make no babies and not take care of 'em or run the streets, fuck up his life. He's gonna do somethin' with himself. Here you come, white and right, and you take one of the few decent men left after jail, drugs and drive-bys. That's what Nikki meant about you up in our world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara sits there, stupefied.    Understanding.    Not understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's only one world, Chenille. (pauses) I thought we were friends. Guess I was wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up, walks out. Something in Chenille wants to call after her, but she's too miserable, too torn up inside to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick and Malakai nurse drinks. The MUSIC fails to move them. They have too much on their minds. Malakai fires up a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many times you gonna ask me that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's payback time. Either you down or you ain't. Either you m'boy or you not. Simple as that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick takes a long moment. The choice is simple. It's the decision that's complicated. He downs his drink. Hedges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if I did ride, you ain't got nobody but Lip and Lip will get a nigger's ass killed. Quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eastside ain't got no firepower. I got some shit, man. AK-47. We go in, get out with one spray down. Just then Snookie and Sara walk toward them from the dance floor. Something in their faces unsettles Sara but Snookie, oblivious, dances up to the bar, snapping his fingers and bobbing his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see us, Patrick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a storm warning) You see us, man? We're rappin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snookie rebuffs him, keeps talking to Patrick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me and Sara lit it up!      Y-e-o-w! ... bumps his butt against Sarah's hip, does a very ungainly half split. Sara and Patrick exchange smiles. Malakai isn't amused. He flattens Snookie's ass with the business end of his foot. Snookie sprawls flat on his face to the floor. Now Malakai's amused. Sara looks at Patrick. Patrick scowls at Malakai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That shit ain't funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (springing up) Damn right it ain't funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you liked it down there. That's your specialty, ain't it? Crawling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was a reflex action, man. And you just plain rude and wrong to bring the shit up in mixed company. Sara's not quite sure what they're alluding to but she doesn't want the displeasure of Malakai's company. She taps Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta get home. Ready? Malakai's eyes slice into her. First Snookie, now this bitch. Steppin' all over his conversation with Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he ain't ready. He's talkin'. To me. A-B conversation. Gotta go? C yourself the fuck home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a real reflex action)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you. Malakai lunges for her. The move is so swift and sudden Patrick overturns his stool to dive between them. He sweeps Sara behind him, into the path of a startled Snookie. Stands there nose-to-nose with Malakai, staring him down, furious with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you lost your motherfuckin' MIND, man? Huh? Have you! Sara, frightened and frozen, doesn't know what to do. Snookie's voice weakly creaks out. He's trying to rise to the occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick, man, c'mon. But Malakai and Patrick stay where they stand. Too close for comfort. Both in the danger zone. Malakai regards Patrick with a combination of cruel anger and deep, genuine hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take that bitch's back and won't even cover mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause you wrong, Malakai!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! You wrong. You BEEN wrong. You ain't worth shit no more. (venomously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out my face, and take that ho with you. Patrick bucks up. Sara walks over to him, gently clutches his sleeve. It's no easier to turn away from Malakai than it is to walk away from a lifetime of friendship. But Patrick does. With Sara holding onto his arm, at his side, he turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: walking. A heavy silence. Sara looks over at him. Patrick doesn't say anything. But after a moment, he reaches down and takes her hand and they walk on like this together. OVER MUSIC (e.g. BUSTA RHYMES' "Dangerous.")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Practice her free form, a hip-hop ballet hybrid. They're both tired, irritable, beaten down. They've been there awhile. Sara makes a misstep. Patrick stops. Cold. Sara grits on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should keep going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You messed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I messed up. I'll get it right the next time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You gonna get it right now so you can do it perfect next time. She glares at him, exasperated.         So many things bo up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't work like this.      I can't dance like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like this.     You dictating to me. He crosses the room, CUTS OFF the MUSIC. Looks at her. Sara walks over to a window seat near him. Flops down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong, Sara?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's wrong. (except) I can't figure things out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What things? The audition? You ain't got nothin' to worry about. I told you. I'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things, Patrick. Things between us. Things between us and them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know there was a 'them.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, open your pretty brown eyes, look the hell around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he's so nonplussed) Everything's screwed up. Nobody wants to see us together, not even Chenille. I don't know why they feel that way. How can I know? Maybe they have a point, Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They only got a point if you believe they got a point, Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him... and loves him... and doesn't know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just saying that we should think about this, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a fuckin' 'nough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you getting mad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I like to think for myself, run my own life, and I thought you did too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara looks at him.     Now she's getting mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're never gonna run your own life as long as you keep running back to Malakai every time he fucks up or fucks you over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's crossed the line. But Patrick responds so deliberately, so calmly prosaic, that she doesn't immediately realize it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all, Malakai ain't never fucked me over. Second of all, you don't know him, Sara, what he been through. Matter of fact, you don't know shit about none of it. So don't come off to me like you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know he's lost, Patrick! Everybody but you can see that. And if you keep reaching back for him, you're gonna wind up lost too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... until he erupts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you to say he's lost? Malakai had my back when you were busy gee-whizzin' in the woods with your backward-ass, redneck friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They weren't rednecks! Patrick yanks his boombox off the floor, glares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what?     The hell with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara yells after him.     Her VOICE ECHOES in the empty studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell with you too!

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Sara exits, looking pretty much like she feels. Like shit. She walks a few paces. Sees Patrick. Their eyes connect for a brief, awful moment before they continue on their respective ways.
