dialogues.speaker: LATER THAT DAY
dialogues.text: Sara's at her locker. Patrick walks up to her. She looks at him, tries to smile past the dour expression on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick doesn't say anything at first.       But then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought you might need this on Saturday. I ain't gonna be able to make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her an audio cassette of her free form music. Sara gazes at it, then up at him, understanding what this means. She won't let him see how it shatters her. He hesitates, as if he wants to say something else. But Sara turns her back on him and Patrick walks away.

dialogues.speaker: TONI
dialogues.text: approaching Sara's locker. Having seen the encounter between Patrick and Sara, she's as smug and overbearing as ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovers' quarrel? You're better off. That menace to society would've broken your heart and spent all your money in a news flash. Trust me on that, Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara stares at her, uncomprehending at first. She resists the urge to slap the smile off Toni's face.   She gets in it instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toni, listen carefully. You're a simple bitch and you don't have any friends, black or white, because nobody likes a fucking asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She storms off leaving Toni, for once, speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara. Caught up in a throng of kids and    somehow very separate from them. The walls have been    transformed in veritable billboards for the senior prom   -- decorations are everywhere. Sara continues down the    hallway almost aimlessly into the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara. Carrying a food tray, eyes searching for a place to sit. She picks up Chenille and her girls at one table... Nikki and her crew at another... Patrick and Snookie... and, finally, Toni. Sara dumps her food into a trash can, walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara. Alone. She pushes the tape from Patrick into an ancient recorder. The MUSIC COMES ON. She takes to the floor. Her face is like a pinched nerve. She wants to cry. She tries to dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara's on the futon, flipping through a photo album. Pictures of her and Glynn. Roy knocks on the partition. Waits a beat before he comes in. He looks at Sara. She keeps flipping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wondering... how long you plan on hating me? Maybe I'm an optimist but I hope there's some kind of timetable. (this raises a small smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't wanna bug you. I just came in to say good luck. Sara regards him quizzically. Roy goes to her dresser, picks up an envelope from Juilliard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw the return address. Got curious. It was open. I read it. I know I shouldn't have but at least now I have an excuse to tell you how proud I am of you, Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly miserable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was gonna tell you about the audition, Roy. I meant to. She's clutching the photo album.    Roy sits down next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow's the big day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.   The big day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bummed out about it? (as she shakes her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a worse liar than I am father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not so bad. (close to a confession) I didn't give you much to work with. It's not like I've been the perfect daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it ain't like I deserve a perfect daughter. I screwed up. Did everything in a hurry and still thought I had all the time in the world. To be in love with your mother. Be a father to you. But time flies. You look up one day and all you got to show for yourself is a pretty little girl who hates your guts and won't talk to you because too much time went by. Sara's eyes well up.    Before she can stop herself, crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't hate you. I miss her. I miss Mom... (as Roy takes her in his arms, tries to console her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Patrick's pissed at me. I'm pissed at him. He's not coming tomorrow and I want him there and I don't know what to do. Sara draws back from Roy, wipes her tears.       Collects herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want him there. I understand that. But whatever he brings to the table, Patrick can't dance for you, Sara. You're the bottom line out there. This is your chance to be the dancer Juilliard came to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted somebody there who loves me. Roy regards her softly, significantly, the irony implicit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara looks up.    For the first time in her life, she believes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick's bouncing on his knees, speaking to Arvel's parents, who are clearly stricken. Arvel's father, stoic, holds his wife's hand. Arvel's mother kneads a Kleenex, her face etched with tears. Patrick hugs her. Stands up to see Malakai frozen in the doorway, put off by the palpable grief. Patrick crosses over to him. They retreat quietly into the corridor, their concern for Arvel a shaky ground for conciliation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why his mom's cryin' like that? Arvel's gonna make it, right? That what's his nurse said. She told me herself, 'Your friend's gonna make it.' Did that bitch lie to me! Talk to me, Patrick! Is he gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick steers Malakai away from the waiting room, backs him against a wall and, in a gentle but firm way, holds him there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just got bad news, man. They don't need to hear it again. (trying to be strong; faltering) Arvel's fightin'. He's gonna pull through. Thing is, when he does, they don't think... he ain't... shit. Arvel ain't gonna walk again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that moment, whatever's left of Malakai's soul crumbles. He looks at Patrick with aggrieved disbelief and then a building anger. A stronger man would probably cry. Patrick eases his grip. Malakai straightens his body, cocks his head slightly. Studies Patrick in this crooked, derisive way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a good reason now, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off Patrick's silence) Aw'ight, college boy. You do what you think is the right thing. I'ma do what I know is the only thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to walk off, doesn't get far before Patrick calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Malakai... (a fleeting hesitation) ... When it's on, I'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Groups of children scatter around worn-out playground equipment. The gleeful squeal of them is everywhere. Patrick guides Christopher down a slide; Chenille catches him at the bottom. Christopher can't get enough of this ride and Patrick and Chenille repeat the routine throughout their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you so quiet? (off Patrick's brooding look) Patrick Reynolds ain't got nothin' to say? That's a first. (catches her son with a whee!; then) You know how I go off on folks sometimes. I mean it and then I don't mean it. Like what I said to Sara. Guess she told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (monotone) I don't care what you said, Chenille.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick. Your ass is on your back and your lips are on the ground. You care, baby brother. And not just about what I said. (as he looks at her) You seriously like Sara. She got a serious jones for you. Am I lyin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's besides the point. Whatever point it is you tryin' to make.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sayin' you can't help who you love, Patrick. At least you found somebody who loves you back. Patrick regards Chenille impassively.    Hands Christophe to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To where? To who? Malakai? (sucks her teeth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't through with that fool yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not a fool, Chenille.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You know what? You're the fool, Patrick. You think you let Malakai down and all you did was try to pull yourself up. Ain't no blame or shame in that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very low; a broken smile) I still gotta go. Check you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding Christopher, Chenille watches Patrick walk out of the playground. Disappear. She and Christopher move on to a seesaw. Chenille bobs him up and down on one end of it. She's snuggling in Christopher's face when the other end suddenly drops to the ground. Chenille looks up. Sees Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're side by side on swings. Christopher's nestled against Kenny's chest, soundly snoozing. They slowly swing throughout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It cut me, what you said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (means this) I shouldn't have... I was trippin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always trip. I'm used to that. Besides, you were right. You were wrong, too. So was I. I need to do better. Ain't no doubt about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I come down on you hard about money, but I would rather you spend the time. Seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jokingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you don't want any money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say all that. He smiles. Gently rubs Christopher's brow.          Looks her. Chenille smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love my son, Chenille.    You know that, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   I always knew that.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: of the building, the downtown skyline, etc.

dialogues.speaker: SAME TIME
dialogues.text: The house lights      are on. Several seats in the front are taken up by      judges for Juilliard. Further back a the families and      friends of other dancers. PUSH IN a FAVOR Roy among      them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warming up, other dancers, all in costume, around her. Her eyes wander from the clock to the stage door.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A sign on it reads: "JUILLIARD SCHOOL OF DANCE - BALTIMORE AUDITIONS." She stares at it, fingers the clover leaf necklace with an unsettling sense of deja vu.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: with a PINCE-NEZ with a clipboard, navigating among the dancers with a clipboard. She calls out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnson.   Sara Johnson...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick's waiting on the sidewalk. Malakai pulls up in Tute's BMW. Lip's in the backseat. Patrick gets into the car. It takes off down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAP MUSIC blasts ON the RADIO. No one in the car is saying anything. Malakai has a "40" between his legs. He sips from it, passes it to Patrick. Patrick takes a short swig, passes it back to Lip. As he does this, a set of keys fall out of his jacket into his lap. Patrick picks them up. Looks at the key chain, his present from Sara. He looks at Malakai.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull over. (as Malakai glances at him, not understanding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ain't helpin' nobody, 'Kai. I'm out. I mean it. Stop the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awww, shit.      Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you mean you out? You think I'ma let your punk ass bail on me again? Patrick starts to open the door. Malakai speeds up. The CAR CAREENS down the street, SQUEALS around corners. Finally comes to a red light. Stops. Patrick starts to open the door. Malakai grabs him by the jacket. Pulls his gun. Patrick looks at Malakai and now he sees him. Sees that he's lost and desperate... and dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you gonna do, 'Kai? You gonna shoot me? Go ahead! You'll have to!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him out!   We don't need him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up. Patrick jerks himself loose. Opens the door. Malakai cocks the gun. Patrick's face flinches at the sound of it. He can feel it trained on his back as he gets out the car. But Malakai can't do it. Wouldn't do it. He takes off like a bat out of hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrick heads down the street. As he walks, he can hear the sound of GUNFIRE behind him, and then the sound like an EXPLOSION. A CAR HORN goes off in a persistent drone. Patrick stops. Stands there for a moment. Then he's walking again. Without looking back. And then he's running away from the mayhem behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BMW's tangled around a street lamp. Inside Malakai slumps over the steering wheel, a bullet through his head.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Pince-Nez leads Sara to the stage.      Announces her. Sara walks onstage. She nods down at the judges, looks out into the audience. Her eyes anxiously search for Patrick... hoping. Her MUSIC begins. Grieg's Peer Gynt (Morning). Sara starts to sway, moving like an angel through the soft cloud of this music. Her line, proportion and balance are impeccable.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tchaikovsky's Swan Lake (Tanz der Schwane) begins and Sara slowly blossoms, opening herself up to the music like a flower. She completes every turn and twist and leap with confidence, energy and persuasion. She is doing what a dancer should do -- engaging the audience, igniting their imagination, drawing them in.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGES
dialogues.text: perking up, taking notes, attentive to her.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: finishes with a flawless arabesque.      Looks out.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGES
dialogues.text: One of the more imperious-appearing JUDGES removes his glasses, speaks to her. Sara's still trying to catch her breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You prepared a free-form?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... sir... they have... my music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it have a theme?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Emo... (clears her throat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emotion. The Judge turns around, shouts to someone we can't see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cue Johnson's music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC UP: A remix of hip-hop (e.g., LAURYN'S HILL'S doo wop; NAS'S "We Will Survive" and JAY Z's latest) and snatches of CLASSICAL.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: stands there. Doesn't move. Can't. She finally walks up to the edge of the stage. Looks down at the judges, her eyes filled with trepidation. Her voice is a shaky whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I wasn't ready.       Can you start it over again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge waving off the MUSIC.      It STOPS.      He re Sara impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you ready now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before she can respond, Patrick's voice booms from the back of the auditorium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.    She's ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE WIDENS to reveal him coming forward. Rushing for the stage. He pauses at the apron of it. Looks up at Sara. She peers down at him, astounded. Shaken. He smiles at her. She smiles back. Patrick's eyes softly take her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can do it. (because) Ain't nobody watchin' you but me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara's eyes focus on him.       She nods.     Turns to th judges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As her MUSIC cues up, Patrick slowly backs away from the stage. Sara begins to dance. She starts out strong and gets stronger. Every emotion she feels, every experience she's had, comes to life in a way that we've never seen before, not even when she was practicing with Patrick. Her body has finally found a way to get inside this kind of music, to elevate its meaning and transform her dance. The MUSIC ENDS.     The lights go up. Sara stands in the middle of the stage breathless, sweating. She lifts her head slowly and the ANGLE WIDENS to reveal --

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Patrick letting out a giant whoop... The judges react and the audience gasps... ... as he bounds onto the stage and... Roy jumps to his feet.      Proudly and loudly clapping. Just like Glynn.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: overwhelmed beyond belief. Patrick's coming toward her. She flies into his arms, free and happy, overjoyed. But the triumph of her performance and the sheer bliss of the moment are transcended by something deeper and clearer, which is her love for Patrick.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGES
dialogues.text: struggling to maintain their and the proceeding's decorum, since the audience, caught up in the throes of this excitement, has begun to loudly, enthusiastically react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, please! (to Patrick) Young man! Get off the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDER to reveal the room. Patrick hugging Sara, looks down at the judges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All due respect, if ya'll don't let this girl in, you're crazy! Sara pulls Patrick back. Walks alone to the edge of the stage, composed and professional again. She regards the judges with a beaming resolve and a ballerina's curtsy, then simply says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.   Very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Johnson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara stops.    Turns back to him.      The Judge smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't say this on the record -- yet. But welcome to Juilliard.

dialogues.speaker: SARA'S FACE
dialogues.text: lovely and radiant as it breaks into a cheek-to-cheek smile. WIDER as she walks slowly, deliberately back to Patrick. Stops. Looks at him. Just looks. And then she throws her arms around his neck, kissing and hugging him. Emotional. Patrick swings her into the air, twirls her around and around, as we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OVER SLOW MUSIC (possible theme song): Sara (in a gown) and Patrick (in a tux). Dancing (as if they had danced from the last FRAME INTO this one). They are beautiful. WIDER to reveal the entire dance floor... And we see that it's the senior prom. The room's dressed up like a dreamy, futuristic romantic illusion. The ceiling's ablaze with tiny, star-like lights; under them large poufs of cotton clouds hang. Glittering, mirrored balls dangle over the main floor. Seniors dance in traditional and cutting edge tuxes and mouth-watering, eye-popping versions of dresses and gowns. CAMERA PANS the floor, PICKING UP: A surprisingly dashing Snookie and the fly girl. As they dance, he bravely but rather too abruptly dips her... Diggy (in a glitter tuxedo and spiked hair) and her date... Nikki with whom we shall perceive to be the Howard University guy. In any event, he looks slightly bored. Chenille with Kenny, smiles at Sara as she and Patrick dance by. CAMERA FAVORS and PUSHES IN ON... Sara and Patrick. Gazing at each other.     The SONG ENDS with them in each other's arms.
